	<item>
				<title>TeachOSM</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=751</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nuala]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=751</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the past three years Nuala Cowan &amp; Richard Hinton of the Geography department at the George Washington University have integrated the open source mapping platform, OpenStreetMap into the curriculum for their introductory undergraduate Geographical Information Systems (GIS) &amp; Cartography classes; traditionally the domain of desktop, proprietary software. Professors Cowan and Hinton have sought to expand the traditional curriculum, and expose students to various different open source software’s, web based platforms, and data collection initiatives, specifically in a service-learning environment.
In collaboration with both local &amp; international partners (American Red Cross 2012, USAID 2014), GW Geography students have used high-resolution satellite imagery to trace road and building infrastructure (Columbia &amp; Indonesia 2012, Kathmandu 2013, Philippines &amp; Zimbabwe 2014), data that is subsequently used to support disaster preparedness efforts. 
Initiated by a small innovative teaching grant we have started work with OpenStreetMap foundation to develop a web site that would allow other instructors to replicate our mapping assignment specific to their particular discipline and curricular needs. This site is called TeachOSM.org. Our funding has since been matched by the World Bank, USAID (OTI and The Geocenter), the State Department and The American Red Cross. With this funding the scope of the project has been expanded to include the redevelopment of the OSM Tasking manager.  The OSM Tasking Manager is a custom-mapping tool that facilitates collaborative mapping projects with a humanitarian focus. The purpose of the tool is to divide a mapping job into individual smaller tasks for group work, while guaranteeing coverage and minimizing overlap.  New additions to the Tasking Manager will allow instructors to assign cells to individual students for both data creation, and data validation roles. 
Mapping has applicability across many fields and communities of interest, and can used to document, archive, plan and contribute to both local and international initiatives.  
Open source mapping modules and assignments are also a unique way to integrate service-learning strategies in course curriculum, while exposing students to new and exciting technological platforms. The experience teaches civic responsibility and the value of collaborative efforts in the global community.
The collaborative mapping initiatives at GWU Geography have been exclusively disaster related to date, as this coincides with the research interests of the faculty involved. We believe this instructional module/assignment is applicable to many disciplines and teaching scenarios, and the objective of the TeachOSM platform is to open that possibility to these other fields, in a comprehensive user friendly way.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Quality of Life Dashboard</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=752</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tobin.bradley]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=752</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Quality of Life project is an ongoing experiment in collaboration across the City of Charlotte, Mecklenburg County, and the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. Culminating in the nationally recognized and 2013 National Association of Counties  Achievement Award winning Quality of Life Dashboard, the Quality of Life project is the story of how passionate people can overcome political and corporate differences to achieve something remarkable.

In this talk we will discuss how the project was built using open source software like Leaflet and D3, opening government data, keys to successful cross-organizational collaboration, and our experience of sharing the Quality of Life Dashboard itself with the community as an open source project.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>An Open Source Approach to Communicating Weather Risks</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=753</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jonathan.wolfe]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=753</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Weather data is a critical element in the decision making process for a vast number of entities and its timely and accurate portrayal is essential. The U.S. National Weather Service has utilized a combination of Open Source projects including: OpenLayers, Qooxdoo, PostGIS and Flot among others to create a mash-up called the Enhanced Data Display or EDD (preview.weather.gov/edd) to promote the development of a Weather Ready Nation. 

The EDD provides a platform to quickly communicate past, current and future weather conditions. What happens over the next couple of hours to a week dictates the agenda of everything from strategic resource placement to what to wear to work. More often than not, the weather forecast is not binary - there is always some probabilistic component that results from the inherent chaos of a 4-D fluid wrapped around a spinning sphere. 

Luckily, the EDD makes use of a variety of techniques that leverage Open Source technologies to present forecasts in both deterministic and probabilistic forms. The EDD contains many visual displays that refine bulky meteorological datasets into more palatable forms. Whether you are looking to see what hazards you may face along a travel route or trying to find a heat map of how many people will be impacted by a tornado warning, the EDD can make this happen quickly. Finally, the ability to combine layers from your own non-weather sources (MapServers, Shapefiles, KML’s) with the layers EDD offers makes this an extremely powerful application. 

The EDD is still in its infancy and there are many more technologies to investigate, but at the moment it is a good example of how combining various Open Source projects can result in an exquisite product.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GIS-based modeling with tangible interaction</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=754</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[akratoc]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=754</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We present advances in the development of TanGeoMS, tangible geospatial modeling and visualization system. By coupling a physical three-dimensional landscape model,  Kinect scanner, projector, and open source GIS software suite GRASS GIS, we created an intuitive tangible interface for dynamic modeling of real-world processes in response to different terrain data inputs. How does it work? You modify the flexible physical model by hands while it is being scanned, imported and processed in GRASS GIS. After computing a desired geospatial analysis or dynamic simulation, the results are projected back on the physical model providing you with instant feedback.
With TanGeoMS we can explore how dune breaches affect coastal flooding, how the spread of fire is influenced by location of firebreaks or what is the effectiveness of various landscape designs for controlling runoff and erosion. We can add buildings and assess the distribution of solar radiation for different building sizes and locations or explore impacts of built structures and trees on line of sight and viewsheds. We will cover new 3D manufacturing technologies and materials we use to create precise physical models and discuss various options for single user and collaborative system designs. Whether you are involved in environmental modeling, decision-making, education or you are just curious, you will find this talk inspiring for your own projects.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>ShapeChange: bridge between data modeling and data distribution</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=772</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mefen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=772</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In Denmark the public authorities register various core information about individuals, businesses, real properties, buildings, addresses, ect.. This information is re-used throughout the public sector. It is a challenging for public authorities to re-use data from different providers to perform their tasks properly and efficiently across units, administrations and sectors. In Danish Geodata agency we have implemented a proof of concept project with the goal of establishing a set of guidelines for future modeling of spatial data for distribution purposes. In this project we have defined a process which starts from the data modelling in UML to the end where data are distributed through WFS services and download services.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Using Geo-Enabled Performance Data to Build Coordination, Transparency, and Historical Context in Overseas Aid Programs</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=774</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[eringoodnough]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=774</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Aid donors fund numerous projects, utilizing contractors and grantees to implement their programming objectives globally. These large project portfolios create significant challenges for those monitoring progress, evaluating program efficacy, and making evidence-based decisions in developing countries. While other fields often embrace high-fidelity performance data, current performance analysis in the aid community remains dependent upon aggregate data, leaving planners and evaluators with a shortage of sub-national data for evaluative and planning purposes and relegating questions of historical context and long-range performance to subjective case studies and anecdotes. 

This presentation provides an open-source proof of concept for collecting, storing, and visualizing/analyzing high-fidelity performance indicator data in a geographic information system.  The proof of concept uses a database that houses the structure for an illustrative project’s performance data entry needs. It uses a real multi-donor dataset from Malawi, Africa, combined with simulated, standardized performance indicator data from the U.S. Foreign Assistance Framework.  The paper presentation is customized for end-users and their management and achieves two objectives: (1) to prove that managing performance data at the sub-national level can be done, and (2) to illustrate the benefits of thinking geospatially in the performance data context.  While this database can be ported over to proprietary or commercial systems, the Boundless stack is explored because of its approachability for novice end-users.  It meets the challenges of basic data entry processes involving a perfect storm of low bandwidth, low capacity and low budget.  Activity performance data are then analyzed for clusters, patterns, and correlations to other data sets, allowing program planners to discern best practices and lessons learned for future program planning and budget allocation. 

Creating an x,y precision standard for collecting performance data is far from mainstream in the aid community.  Socializing this idea via a proof of concept gives end-users and managers a new way to visualize their performance data, share it, and use it.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Lucy: network process services for urban planning</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=775</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[treyer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=775</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Aiming to integrate geo-processing services we introduce a GIS/Geo-design middleware, which we call Lucy. The name is a free interpretation of the acronym U.C. derived from “Urban Communicator”. It implements data conversion and a publish-subscriber (MQTT) service to ensure a fluent communication between different services and clients. Lucy simplifies the workflow when multiple services are used which need to communicate with each other. The technical aspects are shifted away from the users, so that they can primarily focus on their collaborations.

Compared to existing geo-processing standards, Lucy offers a new more comprehensive and still much simpler server framework that lowers the hurdles to offer services across networks. In a later version we will add WPS as part of a webserver module. Lucy is not a webserver, yet it is a Java-based server in a client-server setup. The communication protocol builds on top of TCP/IP connections that are kept open for multiple requests. The communication works with request-answer pairs. Requests and answers are encoded as JSON strings and can be followed by binary streams. Lucy handles requests with pluggable actions (plugins). They  control scenario data, services, and conversion requests. Services (geo-)process on the defined scenario. Lucy distinguishes different categories of plugins: data accesses, actions, services and converters. Services can also run on a remote machine and asynchronous. Therefore it is possible to add and couple services written in various programing languages running on different operating systems.

Inputs of plugins are related to the outputs by using timestamps. This enables Lucy to version data. This is especially interesting for time series of geo-referenced data. Service instances are invoked by MQTT messages. Multiple services can be chained by listening to each other. Default is the Java-based MQTT broker "Moquette" but any MQTT-broker can be configured. Lucy uses data-access-plugins to communicate with different spatial databases. For simplicity reasons, it comes with the Java-based H2 database, and its spatial extension H2GIS. 

Lucy is contained in an executable jar-file which is wrapped in native applications for Windows and OS X. An icon in the system tray provides a basic user interface to access the most important functionalities. The plans for this year include the integration of a Java-based webserver to control service instances as a node-based setup, to observe scenarios in a browser and to integrate WPS. Also planned are client libraries in Java, C#, Python to connect design tools such as Rhino/Grasshopper, Blender and alike.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>775</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

Still, the plans are to make it open source BEFORE the conference. Also, if it would be open source already, this proposal would not remain anonymous.]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
				<title>On using OGC Web Processing Services for computation-intensive tasks in remote sensing and maritime surveillance</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=776</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[espen.messel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=776</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Web Processing Service (WPS) is an OGC standard suitable in particular for high-performance distributed computing in Earth observation applications. 

We employed the open source ZOO WPS platform in a system that tracks and identifies ships observed in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) satellite imagery. In the process, SAR observations are fused with additional data streams from coastal radars and vessel report systems such as AIS. Several separate computation-intensive steps (image processing, data gathering and preparation, and probabilistic tracking) can be combined using simple WPS features for service chaining and remote access to input data. This setup affords some flexibility with respect to performance scaling and distribution of tasks; for example, the image processsing step can be performed by the satellite service provider, on a separate in-house system, or on a WPS server.

Source data and tracking results are stored in a PostGIS database, available to end users via MapServer as WMS/WFS layers in an OpenLayers web client. Using PostGIS, the maps are automatically configured or updated when new data has been produced. The web client supports time-dependent layers, which besides ship tracks also include e.g. meteorological and oceanographical observations and forecasts.

The WPS standard conforms to general principles of service-oriented architectures (SOA), and admits many SOA benefits, such as the incremental development of complex systems by exploiting existing resources. However, few if any WPS servers fully comply with the standard, and from experience several improvements can be proposed, e.g. better options for job management. Simplifying the WPS interface, perhaps using uniform interface semantics as in the REST architectural style, may also help WPS becoming more widely adopted.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>776</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-11 07:27:46</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[developers, end-user, manager]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Authors: Knut Landmark and Espen Messel from Norwegian Defence Research Establishment (FFI)]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Delivering high-resolution global ground state forecasts in a world that expects Google Maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=777</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jyb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=777</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation describes development of a scalable, cloud-based geospatial platform for high-resolution global ground state forecasting (including prediction of soil moisture, soil strength, and water and energy fluxes).  Our platform utilizes daily low-resolution global land surface model (LSM) data to generate ground state forecasts intended for application in disaster management, agriculture, water resources management, and military mobility prediction.  These applications require data resolution on the order of meters.  However, global LSMs, which describe weather and climatic interactions between the Earth’s surface and the atmosphere,  generate ground state output typically on grids of 1/8th degree (~12 km) or coarser.  Although LSMs can potentially run at finer resolutions, the models must be “spun up” with years of historical weather-forcing data, making them unsuited for on-demand ground state simulations.  Instead, our platform loads coarse LSM-generated ground state information and downscales is based on high-resolution topography and soil information using a novel physics-based downscaling model which (1) conserves mass and energy, (2) can be applied at arbitrary points without requiring calculations at surrounding pixels, and (3) can be performed rapidly using standard linear algebra libraries.  Thus, our algorithms efficiently generate high-resolution ground state predictions on spatial grids of arbitrary scale, size, and position.   
In addition, we address end-users expectations that geospatial data be available on-demand and in real time, with extremely low latency, and accessible via intuitive Web-mapping interfaces with smooth, interactive panning and zooming.  By dispatching tile requests to multiple servers, we are able to implement an immersive, low-latency Web-mapping interface in which the real-time processing is transparent to the user.  Map tiles can be served on an arbitrary number of servers with no inter-process communication and without edge artifacts, and the tile generation rate is proportional to the number of servers.   
Our cross-platform software is written primarily in Python and uses several open source libraries.  We use GDAL for geospatial data management and access,  Numpy and Cython for fast numeric, and a highly customized version of MetaCarta’s TileCache for serving and caching WMS tiles.  Our Web site is developed with AngularJS and Flask, and our Web maps are built with OpenLayers.  Our Ubuntu servers are hosted in Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud.  This presentation will discuss software architecture, key algorithmic constraints which must be met in order to implement this type of scheme, and several lessons learned regarding geospatial data staging and caching.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	<item>
				<title>Getting Started with OpenLayers 3</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=778</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tim.schaub]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=778</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[OpenLayers 3 is here! Now it's time to dive in and get mapping. Join us for an overview of OL3 from a user's perspective. We'll cover common use cases and cool features of the library you might not have heard about. Our goal in this presentation is to get you comfortable with the OpenLayers 3 style of mapping - providing an introduction to raster and vector basics, discussing tips for integration with other JavaScript libraries, and exposing you to the build tools so you can choose just the functionality you need for your mapping application.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>778</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-11 08:01:31</wp:post_date>

			<wp:meta_key>schedule_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[13.4.1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_day</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
				<title>Geospatial Distributed Versioning with GeoGit</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=780</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[juan.marin.otero]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=780</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[GeoGit is an open source project that provides a new look at one of the main challenges of geospatial data management: versioning. This talk introduces geospatial distributed versioning and why it's necessary in today's changing computing infrastructure. By adopting concepts and architectures borrowed from the open source programming world, we will see how developers and end users can benefit from the new workflows that this approach offers. We will also review the current status of the project and its future direction, as well as the ecosystem that is growing around it, and how anyone can start using it in their favorite desktop tool or by using web technology.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mobile vector map rendering with Mapbox tools</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=781</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[justin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=781</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Rendering maps from vector data is the next wave in custom cartography, and nowhere is this more important than on mobile devices. Modern mobile devices have high-powered GPUs for hardware-accelerated rendering and a multitude of sensors for environmental input, but also need to be keenly aware of network bandwidth constraints and have the ability to go offline. 

Mapbox is working on a new suite of mobile tools that render constantly up-to-date vector OpenStreetMap data into maps on the device. These maps can be customized completely client-side and even tap into ambient sensors such as GPS, compass, and pedometer. 

This session will show what's possible with this new open source toolkit, including client-side map style customization and influencing the user experience with sensor inputs, and will talk about high-level design goals of the tools and where they are headed next.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Faster and more accurate polygon queries in Lucene Spatial (and Solr and Elasticsearch)</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=782</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jgerard]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=782</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Lucene, and the NoSQL stores that leverage it, support storage and searching of polygonal records.  However the spatial index implementation traditionally has returned false matches to spatial queries.

We have contributed a new spatial indexing strategy to Lucene Spatial, which returns fully accurate results (i.e. exact matches only).  By the time the conference rolls around, we expect to have exposed this feature in Elasticsearch and Solr as well.

Better still, this new spatial search strategy often enables keeping a smaller index and and faster retrieval of results.

I will illustrate why false matches happen --- this requires a high-level walkthrough of spatial index trees.

I'll also demonstrate real cases where this matters.  Our company relies on extremely precise and accurate data: our indexed shapes include legal boundaries, weather readings at 4km resolution, and agricultural sensors down to 1 meter.

To introduce the audience to a solution to the problem, I'll describe our initial workaround -- we've had to query Elasticsearch through a separate server layer that post-filters Elasticsearch results against the query shape, removing the false matches.

We've now built a similar approach into Lucene Spatial itself.  By virtue of living inside, this new solution can take advantage of numerous efficiencies:
 - it filters away false matches before fetching their document contents;
 - it uses a binary serialization that is a hundred times faster than the GeoJSON we used before;
 - it optimizes the tradeoff between work done in the index tree vs. post-filtering, often resulting in a smaller index and faster querying.  I will provide benchmark numbers.

Finally, I'll do a demonstration of how developers and database administrators can use this improvement in their own databases (it's easy!).

While this may sound like a lot of material, it all goes quite fast; the allotted 25 minutes is perfect.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoCouch: A distributed multidimensional index</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=783</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[volker.mische]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=783</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This talk is about GeoCouch, a spatial extension for Couchbase and Apache CouchDB. I will give a quick introduction into Couchbase and Apache CouchDB and why they might be the ideal databases for solving your problem.

With GeoCouch it is not only possible to query your spatial data, but also your spatio-temporal, or even higher dimensions. For example you might want to find all parking lots within a certain area that offer free parking from 3-4 pm and have at least space for 100 cars.

GeoCouch, Apache CouchDB and Couchbase are licensed unter the Apache 2.0 License.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Writing better PostGIS queries</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=784</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=784</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will demonstrate ways to take most advantage of spatial indexes, SQL  constructs, and PostGIS specific functions. For these exercises we'll be using PostGIS 2.1+ and  PostgreSQL 9.3+ . We'll demonstrate common cases people often do inefficiently.

This presentation demonstrates the following
1)	Various SQL constructs including ANTI join, LEFT, RIGHT, EXISTS, LATERAL, CASE clauses, aggregates
2)	What common table expressions (CTEs) are and when to and when not to use them
3)	We'll demonstrate these concepts in use in a couple of common spatial query problems - e.g. proximity analysis (both geometry and geography),  raster analysis and generation, aggregation of data based on various attributes, other correlation queries.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mending Spatial Data with PostGIS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=785</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=785</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation demonstrates common techniques to  clean-up spatial data from a real-world data source.

I will start with raw OSM data.

Topics I'll cover:
1) Getting OSM data
2) How to merge multilinestrings into single linestrings.
3) Fill in gaps, snapping, reducing resolution
4) Consolidating geometries with aggregate functions ST_Union, ST_MakeLine, ST_Collect based on both spatial and non-spatial attributes]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>OpenLayers 3: a unique mapping library</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=786</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[eric.lemoine]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=786</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We've rewritten OpenLayers from the ground up with the goal of offering a powerful, high-performance library leveraging the latest in web technologies. This talk will present the latest advances of the library, focusing on aspects that make OpenLayers 3 stand out. OpenLayers 3, for example, uses technologies, techniques and algorithms that enable high-quality and high-performance vector rendering. Come learn about the optimizations and techniques OpenLayers 3 uses internally, and how you can leverage them in your next web-mapping applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>3D-printing with GRASS GIS – a work in progress in report</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=787</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[peter.loewe]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=787</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As the amount of scientific data continues to grow, researchers need new tools to help them visualize complex data. Immersive data-visualisations are helpful, yet fail to provide tactile feedback and sensory feedback on spatial orientation, as provided from tangible objects. The gap in sensory feedback from virtual objects leads to the development of tangible representations of geospatial information to solve real world problems. Examples are animated globes, interactive environments like tangible GIS, and on demand 3D prints.
The production of a tangible representation of a scientific data set is one step in a line of scientific thinking, leading from the physical world into scientific reasoning and back: The process starts with a physical observation, or from a data stream generated by an environmental sensor. This data stream is turned into a geo-referenced data set. This data is turned into a volume representation which is converted into command sequences for the printing device, leading to the creation of a 3D printout via additive manufacturing (“3D-printing”). As a last, but crucial step, this new object has to be documented and linked to the associated metadata, and curated in long term repositories to preserve its scientific meaning and context.
The development of a reference workflow to produce tangible 3D data-prints from science data was begun at the German Research Centre for Geosciences (GFZ) in 2012. Since 2013, development continues both at GFZ and also the German National Library of Science and Technology. The workflow is entirely based on Free and Open Source Software (FOSS), using both GRASS GIS and Paraview.
The workflow was successfully validated in various application scenarios at GFZ using a RapMan printer to create 3D specimens of elevation models, geological underground models, ice penetrating radar soundings for planetology, and space time stacks for Tsunami model quality assessment. 
While these first pilot applications have demonstrated the feasibility of the overall approach, current research focuses on the provision of the workflow as Software as a Service (SAAS), thematic generalisation of information content and long term curation.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Shortest Path search in your Database and more with pgRouting</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=790</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dkastl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=790</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[pgRouting extends the PostGIS / PostgreSQL geospatial database to provide shortest path search and other network analysis functionality. 

This presentation will show the inside and current state of the pgRouting development, from its wide range of shortest path search algorithms to driving distance calculation or “Traveling Sales Person” (TSP) optimization. Additionally we will give a brief outlook and introduction of upcoming new features like the  “Vehicle Routing Problem” (VRP) solver, and what we have in mind for future releases. 

We will explain the shortest path search in real road networks and how the data structure is important to get better routing results. Furthermore we will show how you can improve the quality of the search with dynamic costs and make the result look closer to the reality. You will also learn about difficulties and limitations of the library, and when pgRouting might not be not the right tool to solve your routing problem.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Location-based Task Management for Mobile Business</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=791</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dkastl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=791</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Salesmen need to visit their customers, city officers need to check public assets, outpatient care staff needs to visit patients, … and there are lot of other examples where tasks have a geospatial reference. 
To manage such work with information technology implies more than just dropping a marker on a map: location-based tasks usually pass through various states, have varying importance, get assigned to different people and follow a predefined workflow. Activities must be documented, working hours need to be tracked. Whether local government or (small) businesses, on-site work is often managed in an old-fashioned and rather inefficient way. 
With optimization of work processes and tour scheduling in mind we have started to build a task management software based on available open source software and open standards. In this presentation you will learn about our concepts, and how FOSS4G can facilitate on-site customer services and improve service quality and efficiency.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Fusing Structured and Unstructured Data for Geospatial Insights in Lumify</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=792</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[greenbacker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=792</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Lumify is an open source big data integration, analytics, and visualization platform designed to help users discover connections and explore relationships in their data. It can ingest anything from spreadsheets and text documents, to images and video, representing this diverse data as a collection of entities, properties, and relationships between entities. Everything is stored in a scalable and secure graph database to enable advanced social network analysis and complex graph traversals. Built on proven open source technologies for big data like Hadoop, Storm, and Accumulo, Lumify supports a variety of mission-critical use cases centered around the emerging concepts of activity-based intelligence (ABI), object-based production (OBP), and human geography (HG). Its intuitive web-based user interface provides a suite of analytic options with multiple views on the data, including 2D and 3D graphs, full-text faceted search, histograms with aggregate statistics, and an interactive geographic map exploration feature. This talk will demonstrate how Lumify can be used to fuse structured and unstructured data from multiple sources into a unified knowledge base, and then analyze that knowledge to uncover hidden connections and actionable insights buried within the data's geospatial context.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Government as a Contributing Member of the OpenStreetMap (OSM) Community</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=793</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mchughb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=793</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[OpenStreetMap (OSM) is now TriMet’s standard source for routable base map data.  TriMet utilizes OSM for internal systems and applications that necessitate a routable base map including, but not limited to: Computer-Aided Dispatch/Automatic Vehicle Location (CAD/AVL) system; Call Center and Field Trip applications; LIFT paratransit mobile data terminals (MDTs); OpenTripPlanner, an open source, multimodal trip planner; and fixed route scheduling system for on-street service.   

TriMet is now a committed, contributing member of the OSM community.  Working with the community and local jurisdictions is a standard business practice supported with a full-time employee (FTE) that is dedicated to OSM maintenance and associated datasets in the seven counties area. This effort sustains the increasing number of systems in the agency that require routable networks, and it supports seamless multi-agency trip planning and analysis in the region.  

This presentation will include: 
•	Emerging technologies on the market that require a seamless routable network, and why OSM is an obvious solution to fulfill new system requirements 
•	TriMet’s OSM Improvement Projects for the seven county regional area in Portland in support of vehicle, walking, biking and transit routing  in the four county metro area 
•	The business justification for a dedicated FTE in support of continued maintenance of OSM 
•	The financial support for this position which demonstrates the recognition of OSM’s importance from both an agency and regional perspective.  
•	Benefits of collaboration between the OSM community and government 
•	Facilitation of  progress in this area with open data policies, data portals, and enhanced software tools]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>793</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-13 13:38:47</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

	<item>
				<title>Open source, open standards and 50 lines of code: A look behind GitHub&#039;s GeoJSON rendering and diffing</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=794</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ben]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=794</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last June, GitHub announced support for GeoJSON rendering — just commit and you have a versioned, open-source map. Six months later, visual GeoJSON diffing followed suit. Since then, GitHub hosts hundreds of thousands of GeoJSON files, has served millions of maps, and has diffed tens of thousands of changes, both proposed and realized. Why GeoJSON? Why Leaflet? Why openstreetmap? We'll take a look at both the technical how, and the philisophical why, and pull back the curtain on GitHub's recent venture into the world of GIS.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Creating an Imagery Management Backend for Distributed Knowledge Discovery Workflows</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=795</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nugentpj]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=795</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will address a case study in building a satellite imagery management system leveraging multiple open source projects and open standards.  The purpose of the system is to allow a flexible means for high performance query, access, and retrieval of satellite imagery within an automated and distributed knowledge discovery workflow. The system is distinct from a spatial data infrastructure, for which the principal purpose is to share spatial data resources among stakeholders, in that the audience will not be exclusively human and interfaces will be machine-readable and geared towards information extraction.  However, requirements for this use case also include providing interfaces to accommodate human interaction, such as building training models for a supervised learning workflow, submitting jobs to a massively parallelized image processing chain, and delivering editable output to the user in a collaborative, version-controlled environment.  This is achieved through a web client that allows very large imagery, models, and output to be visualized and modified on the fly.  Among this project’s technical requirements are to extract and index metadata from large raster datasets; query vast amounts of metadata over spatial and temporal coverages and imagery characteristics; and allow on-demand terrain correction and visualization of imagery.  This presentation will address the challenges, caveats, and novel findings of building such a system.]]></content:encoded>

the software components we use to accomplish this, as well as discussing challenges and solutions in this process.  With luck I will be in a position to show off our global mosaics, and offer Planet Labs open source compositor software.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Image Rectification at Planet Labs</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=797</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Planet Labs is collecting images from dozens of satellites.  The process and techniques for automating the ortho-rectification of these images will be discussed in some detail, including the open source components underlying the processing chain, processing challenges and solutions.  Noteworthy aspects include techniques for developing generic geometry models (RPCs) for  scenes, and techniques for tieing down loosely positioned images to a global basemap image.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Crazy data: Using PostGIS to fix errors and handle difficult datasets</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=798</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daniel_a_miranda]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=798</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Inteligeo is a system that stores a lot of information used by the Brazilian Federal Police Forensics to fight crime, initially in the environmental arena with a later expansion to other types of crime. During the construction of the database a lot of problems appeared for which PostGIS was the key to the solution.
This presentation describes problems encountered by the team while loading 850+ shapefiles into the database, linking with external databases and building 950+ views of the data.
Although the content of the recipes is very technical, the general concepts will be explained in an accessible language and correlated to real world cases.

Topics:
*Definition of crazy data in our context
*Quick recipes
- Spike removal
- Invalid geometry detection and fixing
- Filling holes
- Raster image footprints
- Hammering data into correct topologies
- Speeding data visualization with ST_Simplify and PGSQL 9.3's materialized views
- Rough georeferencing using an auxiliary table
- Creating constraints
*How is crazy data generated and our experience in handling each case
- Large datasets
- Lack of validation
- Reprojection
- Geometric operations
- Topological errors
- Imprecise definitions
- Legacy databases
- Bad georeferencing

We will also discuss why is handling crazy data important for the Brazilian Federal Police, our efforts in cleaning up data at the source and the implications of geographical data in general for fighting crime.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Basin units Mapping by using QGIS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=799</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jangsh]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=799</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Republic of Korea Ministry of National Institute of Environmental Research being in progress  Basin units Mapping in order to update Status of watershed planning and the amount of water usage, environmental facilities etc.(for manage water pollution). Previously, Mapping was progressed by using ArcMap. But nowadays overall mapping is progressed by using QGIS. After describe how to create basin units map by using Arcmap and QGIS, advantages and disadvantages of these two tools are analyzed and provide production techniques through the QGIS.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>799</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-13 22:42:37</wp:post_date>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Using Q GIS　as making tidal flat present state map</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=800</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jiwon93147]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=800</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Making tidal flat present state map is one of the task of the Korean governmental organization “Ministry of oceans and fisheries” every 5 years. Tidal flat takes 3 percents of Korean territory, tidal flat has the function of purifying pollutants from overland. 
According to our experiment, 10 Kilo meters(Km) of tidal flat can purify water pollutants from a hundred thousand populated and 25.3Km sized city. Realizing and making tidal flat present state map is taking action for the formulation of the new national preserving tidal flat policy.
Arc GIS　software was used as the 2013 version of tidal flat present state map.
I believe that Q GIS system can fix the problems which occurred while making the map with Arc GIS software.
With Arc GIS software it was hard to define tidal flat and land locations but with the Q GIS　software, it provides satellite pictures so it is much easier to specify borders between land and tidal flat, therefore it is able to make the map more neatly and correctly.
More over this year the first test version of “Tidal flat present state map by satellite analysis” was released, while making the map with Arc GIS it was hard to choose satellite pictures.
When we select satellite pictures, we need to care about the cloud effect, current difference between north and south plus much more things and along with Arc GIS we had difficulty considering all of these things but if we use Q GIS, we can use open source map such as “NAVER map”, “DAUM map” therefore I assume that it is possible to make more convenient and clear map.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Introducing of spatial data supported web-based DB Query tool, Tadpole</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=801</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jangbi882]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=801</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tadpole is open source web-based DB tool, developed from 2011. The offical name is ‘Tadpole DB Hub’.
Tadpole support traditional RDB like as Oracle, PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, SQL Server, CUBRID, and also support Hadoop based DB and DW like as MongoDB, Hive, Tajo, and support Cloud DB Amazone RDS. 

In this year, we started attaching spatial data support. In FOSS4G 2014, we will demonstrate Tadpole, that support PostGIS, SQL Server, MySQL, Oracle.
It will can display queried spatial data on OSM Map, can modify spatial data by WKT.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Big size meteorological data processing and mobile displaying system using PostgresSQL and GeoServer</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=803</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jhkwun]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=803</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Gaia3D has developed meteorological data mobile web service using PostgresSQL and GeoServer for weather forecaster in Korea Meteorological Administration(KMA).This system  displays weather charts, weather prediction information, weather images, observation data on mobile web for rapid decision of weather forecasters when they are out of office or in remote environment. I will deliver a presentation about experience to develop and launch mobile web service showing weather charts by tuning daily updated big spatial data in terms of database.

Weather charts generated by this system are displayed using OpenLayers Mobile after inserting big size vector data into PostGIS and rendering these data by GeoServer. This system processes 67 million lines of spatial data(approximately 35GB) and generates more than five thousands weather charts everyday.

On previous system, it took five hours to insert data into PostGIS and took tens of seconds to publish single weather charts by GeoServer. Also, there was another problem that file size on PostGIS has unlimitedly increased.

Gaia3D decided to fix the problems and improve this system in terms of data input, data management, and data display. Consquently, the performance of data input has increased about hundred times and the performance of data display has increased about two hundred times. Finally, KMA could successfully and stablely manage the system without increase of file size of three days data.(This system shows data up to previous 72 hours.)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Wikimaps Atlas : Wikipedia, D3js, SVG maps for webdevs.</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=807</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[hugo.lpz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=807</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[#Problem:
Making encyclopedic maps for Wikipedia is currently a highly manual process resulting in a poor supply of maps that is unable to meet the demand of accurate and updated maps for various projects and languages.
#Solution:
Automate the creation of SVG base maps in a well researched cartographic style using the latest and most accurate open geographic data.

#How: automatizing the cartographer's workflow for the basemaps creation
The Wikimaps Atlas (2014) project —currently under development— is a centralized, automatized, systematic way to produce the most needed and most difficult to create base layers. The central concept is to greatly simplify the mapmaking workflow by separating (1.) the map-data script-processing to generate accurate and elegant background, from (2.) the process of map design : selecting relevant encyclopedic items and events to display and explain upon a geographic area. The job of the project members is to provide a system which will crop, slice, simplify, filter, stylize these huge GIS files in order to provide a final SVG background of about 100~500KB each which will be fine for the end users, his/her web browser, and the WMF's servers.
#Encyclopedic maps with elegance &amp; style
Building upon well established best practices (colorschemes) and handmade workflows refined for years by the Wikipedia Map Workshops, following the Wikipedia:Kartenwerkstatt/Positionskarten project, WikiAtlas will provide volunteer wikipedia cartographers and graphists a complete and consistent set of high quality base maps, so these volunteer graphists may focus on designing semantics layers representing and explaining a given encyclopedic topic. Following clean and standard graphic guidelines, we want these maps to be elegant, consistent, readable, accessible to the reader, altogether building a graphical identity and feel for Wikipedia and for maps on Wikipedia. We want these maps to be standalone maps, so they stay easy to edit, print, embed, and spread inside and outside Wikipedia, by editors, journalists, web-developers. We also want these maps to be well coded SVG documents, with some hidden meta-data serving as anchors, so data and interactions may be bidden to them.
#System: sources and main requirements
The system reuse existing and notable graphic guidelines (best practices), various available online open GIS data and layers from providers like Natural Earth, OpenStreetMap, NASA, GADM.org etc (public domain, CC-by-sa-3.0), as well as web oriented data visualization technologies (D3js, topojson). The system keeps relevant metadata allowing to categorize maps and conserve traces of geolocalisation, so when on commons, it in effect create the first systematic, complete, and consistent atlas of free and open stand alone maps. The Wikimaps Atlas project is to generates all the set of target maps for countries, provinces, subunits, and custom areas under request. This set being about 5.000 basemaps easy to update, a major improvement for wikipedia map resources, in terms of reliability, scope, and content management.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[The team and presentation are officially funded by the Wikimedia Media Foundation.
The project will be functional this summer 2014. We wish to publicly announce and introduce the project to the FOSS4G conference.
http://wikimapsatlas.github.io]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpuf_form_id</wp:meta_key>

			<wp:meta_key>schedule_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[22.8.1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_day</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_session</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_track</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[8]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Using QGIS server</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=808</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karl-magnus.jonsson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=808</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Kristianstad municipality in Sweden has since 2013 been using QGIS and QGIS Server as a base in our GIS platform. Our goal is to have a user friendly, yet powerful, set of applications from server via desktop and web to mobile applications. All based on open source. QGIS and QGIS server has several functions that makes it easier for both the users and administrators of the systems. That could be saving styles and attrib-ute forms to the database, styling and publish WMS and WFS directly from the desktop QGIS application. With a combination of different types of caching mechanisms we achieve fast and flexible services for our web applications. These open source projects, sMap and sMap-mobile, have also been designed to be fast, flexible and user friendly.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>&quot;Fast Big Data?&quot; A High-Performance System for Creating Global Satellite Image Time Series</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=810</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dswanepoel1]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=810</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Description:
We describe a system that transforms sequences of MODIS images covering the entire Earth into time-optimized data cubes to provide rapid access to time series data for various applications.

Abstract:
Satellite time series data are key to global change monitoring related to climate and land cover change. Various research and operational applications such as crop monitoring and fire history analysis rely on rapid access to extended, hyper-temporal time series data. However, converting large volumes of spatial data into time series and storing it efficiently is a challenging task. In order to solve this Big Data problem,  has developed a system which is capable of automated downloading and processing of several terabytes of MODIS data into time-optimized "data cubes." This time series data is instantly accessible via a variety of applications, including a mobile app that analyzes and displays 14 years of vegetation activity and fire time series data for any location in the world. In this presentation we will describe the implementation of this system on a high-performance Storage Area Network (SAN) using open source software including GDAL and HDF5. We discuss how to optimally store time series data within HDF cubes, the hardware requirements of working with data at this scale as well as several challenges encountered. These include writing high-performance processing code, updating data cubes efficiently and working with HDF data in a multi-threaded environment. We conclude by showing visualizations of our vegetation and burned area time series data in QGIS, web apps, and mobile apps.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>sMap-mobile – a framework for creating maps with a responsive design</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=811</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[johan.lahti]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=811</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[sMap-mobile is a software framework for web maps, built with Leaflet and Bootstrap. The framework can be extended with Leaflet controls, allowing for easy integration with other Leaflet frameworks and applications.

Our goal with the framework is to make it easy to create tailor-made maps that work on any device. The framework is therefore built with a “responsive web design”. This means, the interface adapts to the screen width of the device. Many responsive features come for free with Bootstrap – but some features need to be invented from scratch to fit in a map context.

In this presentation we will present our thoughts and solutions to achieve a responsive design for web maps. We will also present the framework and invite others to take part of the functionality as well as to contribute to the project on GitHub.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapJakarta - Enabling civic co-management through GeoSocial Intelligence</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=812</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tomas]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=812</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Mapping urban infrastructure systems is a key requirement to advance our capacity to understand and promote the resilience of cities to both extreme weather events as a result of climate change and to long-term infrastructure transformation as a process of climate adaptation. Yet, while developing nations will bear the brunt of the interwoven, climatic, economic and social challenges of the 21st century, many of these countries lack the sensor networks required to monitor and model the response of the urban system to change. The nexus of people and place embedded in social media communication which is widespread and ubiquitous in many developing nations offers one potential solution. In this context, location-based social media often in the form of big-data, can be used to map emerging spatio-temporal trends to support situational management. Critically, however, the collection and application of such data raises significant questions around privacy, trust and security of the information gathered. The MapJakarta.org project will be presented as a demonstration of the capabilities of free and open source geospatial technology to employ real-time social media data in a secure and anonymous manner for the purpose of decision support.

MapJakarta.org is a pioneering web-based platform that harnesses the power of social media by gathering, sorting and displaying information about flooding for Jakarta residents and governmental agencies in real time. The project, in partnership with the Flood Management Office in Jakarta (BPBD DKI) will radically change real-time data collection and feedback for flood monitoring in the most densely populated city in Southeast Asia. The platform runs on the open source software known as CogniCity – a GeoSocial Intelligence framework developed by the SMART Infrastructure Facility, University of Wollongong – which allows situational information to be collected and disseminated by community members through their location enabled mobile devices via social media networks. Furthermore, the framework also enables governmental actors to perform rapid infrastructure surveys and asset management for pre and post-flood assessment using the same networks. CogniCity is built on the NodeJS platform, and utilizes the PostGIS spatial database for storage, and the LeafletJS map library for visualisation. 

In this presentation we will explain how these open source components are combined to form a geographical information system within the existing flood management framework, enabling the collection and analysis of social media for flood response and civic co-management in the megacity of Jakarta.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>LocationTech Projects</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=814</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jgarnett]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=814</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[LocationTech is an Eclipse Foundation industry working group for location aware technologies. This presentation introduces LocationTech, looks at what it means for our industry and the participating projects.

Libraries: JTS Topology Suite is the rocket science of GIS providing an implementation of Geometry. Mobile Map Tools provides a C++ foundation that is translated into Java and Javascript for maps on iOS, Andriod and WebGL. GeoMesa is a distributed key/value store based on Accumulo. Spatial4j integrates with JTS to provide Geometry on curved surface.

Process: GeoTrellis real-time distributed processing used scala, akka and spark. GeoJinni mixes spatial data/indexing with Hadoop.

Applications: GEOFF offers OpenLayers 3 as a SWT component. GeoGit distributed revision control for feature data. GeoScipt brings spatial data to Groovy, JavaScript, Python and Scala. uDig offers an eclipse based desktop GIS solution.

Attend this presentation if want to know what LocationTech is about, are interested in these projects or curious about what projects will be next.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>814</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 05:50:56</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[LocationTech, Software Foundation, Eclipse Foundation, JTS, Mobile Map Tools, GeoMesa, Spatial4j, GeoTrellis, GeoJinni, GEOFF, GeoGit, GeoScript, uDig]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[developers, managers, open source advocates]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>State of GeoTools 2014</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=815</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jgarnett]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=815</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[GeoTools is one of the largest, and fastest moving, OSGeo projects. Attend this talk for a status report on the project and a preview of what to expect next.

This presentation provides a review of new features, api changes and community modules. We have simplified the core FeatureCollection interface, introduced partial 3D support, structured grid coverages, multiple grid coverages.

Data formats support continues to grow with the latest GeoPackage, native NetCDF support and a new shapefile and wfs store implementation. Database support continues to improve with table and index management methods.

Extensions have seen a lot of activity with improvements to WMS client, an extension for vector grids, and more. A transform module has been introduced to allow for dynamic feature collection processing.

Attend this talk for a cheerful update on what is happening with the GeoTools community.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoServer Feature Frenzy</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=816</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jgarnett]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=816</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What can you do with this GeoServer thing? This talk covers some of the basic (and not so basic) ways to use GeoServer to publish your geospatial data and make it look great!

GeoServer made its first release in 2001 and has grown into an amazing, capable and diverse program. This also means the “feature list” is spread over years of release announcements, presentations, mailing list archives!

This presentations provides a whirlwind tour of GeoServer and everything it can do today!

This talk is a visual guide to the features of GeoServer. Are you just getting started with GeoServer, or considering it for the first time? Attend this talk and prioritize what you want to look into first. Are you an expert user who has been running GeoServer since Java 1.4? Attend this talk and see what tricks an optimisations you have been missing out on!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>State of GeoServer 2014</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=817</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jgarnett]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=817</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Take the pulse of the project with a status report on how GeoServer is doing and what to expect next.

The presentation will start with a “year in review” overviewing some of the new and noteworthy of the past year. This past year saw the coming of GeoServer 2.5, and we are going to release 2.6 around FOSS4G. Both these releases have a number of exciting new features: WCS 2.0 and WCS 2.0 Earth Observation profile, addition of batch importer, new GetFeatureInfo implementation.  A passion for performance sees improvements in PNG and JPEG encoding, rendering from PostGIS and experimental JDK work. Attend this presentation to get the entire report of what happened in the past year.

GeoServer development is very active with a  number of exciting features in the pipeline. The remainder of the presentation will focus on the future with a report of the new developments currently being worked on and what new features and improvements users can expect in 2015.

Whether you are an expert user, a developer, or simply curious what GeoServer is and what it can do for you, this talk is for you.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>An automated classification and change detection system for rapid update of  land-cover maps of South Africa using Landsat data.</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=818</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mcalisterb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=818</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Recent land cover maps are essential to spatial planning and assessment by  non-/governmental agencies. The current land cover mapping methods employed in South Africa are slow and expensive and the most recent national land cover map dates back to 2000. The CSIR is developing an automated land-cover mapping system for the South African region. This system uses widely available Landsat  satellite image time series data, together with supervised machine learning, change detection, and image preprocessing techniques. In this presentation the implementation of this end-to-end system will be addressed. Specifically, we will discuss evaluation of open source random forest implementations (Weka, scikit), a change detection algorithm (IRMAD), as well as tools used for satellite image preprocessing (Web enabled Landsat data, fmask cloud masking) and on-line validation tools. Furthermore the approach used in optimising automatic land-cover production accuracy for operational use will be discussed.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapCache: Overview of MapServer&#039;s tile caching server</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=819</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[thomas.bonfort]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=819</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MapCache is the MapServer project's implementation of a tile caching server. It aims to be simple to install and configure, to be (very) fast (written in C and running as a native module under apache or nginx, or as a standalone fastcgi instance), and to be capable (services WMTS, googlemaps, virtualearth, KML, TMS, WMS). When acting as a WMS server, it will also respond to untiled GetMap requests, by dynamically merging multiple layers into a single image, and multiple tiles into an arbitrary image size. Multiple cache backends are included, allowing tiles to be stored and retrieved from file based databases (sqlite, mbtiles, berkeley-db), memcached instances, cloud REST containers (S3, Azure, Google Cloud Storage), or even directly from tiled TIFF files. Support of dimensions allows storing multiple versions of a tileset (e.g. one per customer), and time based requests can be dynamically served by interpreting and reassembling entries matching the requested time interval. MapCache can also be used to transparently speedup existing WMS instances, by intercepting getmap requests that can be served by tiles, and proxying all other requests to the original WMS server. Along with an overview of MapCache's functionalities, this presentation will also address real-world usecases and recommended configurations.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Fast Travel Sheds using GTFS Data in GeoTrellis Transit</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=823</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jbranigan]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=823</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS) data is the open standard for representing transit systems in space and time. While developing an open source planning application for public transit agencies, it became clear that processing speed was the primary impediment to calculating transit coverage indicators within a reasonable time. At a glance, GTFS is just a set of simple CSV files organized relationally with key fields. But transit systems are far more complex than just spatial data for routes and stops.  They need to be able to model spatial-temporal relationships embodied in transit schedules as well as semi-cyclical and shifting schedule patterns. Additionally, the specification is flexible enough to represent many different approaches to operating transit systems and the same system attributes can often be represented in multiple ways.

While some transit system metrics are fairly straightforward to compute, certain public transit system metrics are best modeled as “travel shed” represented by raster coverages or isolines derived from them. The GeoTrellis Transit project is an extension of the open source GeoTrellis framework and was created to calculate travel shed rasters using GTFS and OpenStreetMap data. GeoTrellis Transit accomplishes this by creating a time-dependant graph structure that can rapidly perform shortest path queries at a given time of day, based on the public transit schedule. 

The challenge in developing GeoTrellis Transit involved designing a time-dependent graph structure that contains information about how the nodes connect at any particular moment in time during traversal. Shortest path algorithms on time-dependant graphs need to take into account arrival times at any given node, as well as wait times until an edge becomes available. This makes fast calculation of shortest path trees on time-dependant graphs difficult, which GeoTrellis Transit optimizes using a novel data structure to represent the graph. 

This presentation will introduce the GTFS standard and identify where difficulties may arise, especially for large systems. It will also describe how GTFS, OpenStreetMap and GeoTrellis Transit can be combined to build a fast time-dependant graph structure that can then be used to create time-based shortest path trees and travel shed rasters.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
