	<item>
				<title>Inteligeo - Geographic Intelligence System in the Brazilian Federal Police</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=825</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daniel_a_miranda]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=825</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is a case study about using WebGIS for fighting crime from a forensics standpoint.
When one thinks about GIS for law enforcement, vehicle tracking and messaging immediately comes to mind. Inteligeo provides support for law enforcement in a different manner: it provides information for the forensics examiner.

The system became operational in November 2010 and it now has more than 850 themes and 950 data visualization layers, and is available only inside of the Brazilian Federal Police internal network. It started as tool for fighting environmental crime, now it covers a wide variety of subjects such as environmental data, chemical analysis of pesticides, mining operations, public works fraud and legal status of rural properties. We also have a raster data repository and integration with databases from several institutions.

The system uses a fully open source database. After a difficult migration from a proprietary database, the data can now be handled not only by the proprietary GIS framework, but also by tools from the open source ecosystem and by our own maintenance tools.

During almost four years of operations, some lessons have been learned and the initial strategic plans have changed. We will discuss issues such as what can be outsourced and what has to be made in house, decisions regarding the database, experimenting versus focusing, key features (our) users use most, demonstrating value to internal management.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The Denver Regional Equity Atlas</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=828</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jtodd]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=828</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Denver Regional Equity Atlas (www.denverregionalequityatlas.org) is a tool to help raise awareness among a wide range of stakeholders about the benefits and opportunities that a robust public transportation network can create.  This interactive tool provides users with the ability to create and share maps that depict the region’s major origins and destinations in relation to the current and future transit network. Its development is a great story of open source users collaborating together in order to develop a tool for the Denver region’s planning community.  In its first few months of its launch, the application has received a lot of community-level attention and praise. The success of this application was made possible both through the current maturity of the tools chosen as well as the flexibility of the development team.
  
  The Denver Regional Equity Atlas was developed using GeoKettle, PostgreSQL and PostGIS, SQL Server and ASP .NET MVC, GeoServer, Leaflet.js and D3.js.  Audience members should have interest in web mapping with open source (mostly) geo stacks, Leaflet.js, and charting with D3.js.  This presentation will appeal to both users who are just getting started with FOSS4G tools as well as developers who would like to see how their tools are used.  Audience members will be introduced to high level project information and will be given an overview of the development process.  The presentation will provide emphasis on data centric topics, such as the evolution of the data and data processing techniques.   The presentation will also lightly touch on client-side programming using Leaflet.js and D3.js.  At the end of this presentation, participants will have learned about the various tools used to develop the Denver Regional Equity Atlas and will hopefully be inspired to utilize some of these tools in their own applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Adopting OGC Standards in a Flood Alert System</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=829</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ivanfm]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=829</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation is about the adoption of the OGC - Open Geospatial Consortium standards in our Flood Alert System which was based on matrix coordinates and static maps. 

The Flood Alert System has more than 300 telemetric stations composed by rain gauges, water level sensors placed on rivers and reservoirs, water quality sensors, weather stations and a S-band weather radar reaching 240 kilometers of scanning range. The system offers Real Time support for a large metropolitan area and its Emergency Centers, Civil Defense groups, Government, Service companies and general public.

We have integrated Geotools (for data conversion), Geoserver (services like WMS, WFS), DB2, OpenStreetMap, uDig, Quantum GIS and some other softwares in our architecture. This set of tools provides many possibilities to easily integrate our data with other systems and external data, like some Hydraulic and Hydrological models that return geospacial data with flooding area forecast and vulnerable buildings.

Talking about the architecture, the adoption process, some of the issues, apllied solutions and further development.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Vector tiles for fast custom maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=830</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dane]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=830</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Vector tiles are becoming a common solution for fast clientside rendering of spatial data in both browsers and mobile devices. With the recent release of TileMill 2 Mapbox has made it easier to design and render vector tiles. This talk will cover the open source technology under the hood in TileMill 2 as well as other available tools. Also discussed will be the status of an emerging specification for vector tiles and recent advances in the format.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Fixing GIS Data Discovery</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=831</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pjreed]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=831</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Discovery of GIS data is broken. It is overly complicated and incomplete. Organizations spend time and money on creation and acquisition of data, yet it sits on hard drives, dvd’s, and shelves without a straightforward way for others to discover it. Discovery tools that do exist have usability issues which alienate users and prevent wide adoption. Too often, data discovery is an afterthought, grafted onto tools that have been designed for analysis, or treated as one feature among many in a map portal. Thus these tools attempt to serve every possible user need and in the process become unusable. Simply put, we need an application which enables discovery of GIS data with an emphasis on user experience, integrates seamlessly with other tools, and streamlines the use and organization of geospatial data.

We present GeoBlacklight, a collaboratively designed and developed open source software focused on discovery use cases. The project builds on existing, widely adopted open source projects. GeoBlacklight fills the gap in discovery tools for geospatial data by providing a simple, yet powerful intuitive interface. To reach this goal, Stanford University embarked upon a comprehensive design process. Our	process includes an environmental scan, stakeholder interviews, user interviews, inter-institutional collaboration, and rapid prototyping. We will present the user personas that have been distilled from our interviews, the user stories and feature prioritization process these inform, and prototypes of the software we have developed so far, as well as plans for future development.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Creating Charts and Legends for 3D Atlas Maps - A Mashup of D3.js, osgEarth, and the Chromium Embedded Framework</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=832</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[schnuerer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=832</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation introduces a mashup of the JavaScript library D3.js, the virtual globe toolkit osgEarth, and the web browser engine Chromium Embedded Framework. Using the example of a national atlas, it is demonstrated how these OpenSource frameworks facilitate the creation of charts and legends for a series of three-dimensional maps. Compared to previous in-house developments, this approach keeps the source code at a minimum but still maintains the flexibility of further extensions.

The first part of the presentation explains how to derive a 3D chart map from multivariate point data: Charts are defined in osgEarth configuration files, generated in the DOM of the Chromium Embedded Framework, transferred back as SVG documents, and displayed as billboards in the virtual globe. So far, six widely used chart types (i.e. pie, ring, wing, divided area, bar, and divergent bar charts) with individual properties could be implemented. This selection enables to show statistical data in an appealing and interesting way to the public.

In the second part, legends for choropleth, line, symbol, and raster maps are presented. They allow to depict unique values, value ranges, and combinations of those having two dependent variables. Also legend templates for color gradients and hierarchical categories have been developed. All legends are made with D3.js and superimposed the virtual globe, thus helping the atlas user to resolve the meaning of map features.

Finally, current limitations of the chosen approach are discussed and future work of the atlas project is outlined. Overall, the mashup provides a good synthesis of traditional cartography and modern OpenSource technologies. The JavaScript code for creating charts and legends may be reused in other contexts (e.g. WebGL) and for other cartographic products.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>832</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 09:37:33</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>GIS in the Browser - The Good Parts</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=833</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mpriour]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=833</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Long gone (hopefully) are the days of replicating the "professionals only" desktop GIS interface in a browser. However, with modern browsers, HTML5 APIs, and increased efficiency of javascript engines it is possible to performantly replicate GIS functionality in a purely client-side browser application. Moderately complex geoprocessing, persistent client-side storage and simple to complex data visualization are all possible now. We walk through the underlying technology and demonstrate the practical use of it in an open-source sample application. Technologies covered include IndexedDB, WebStorage, Workers, Strongly Typed Arrays and Canvas. Some attention will also be paid to performance limitations, browser support and polyfills for older browsers.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mapping with AngularJS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=834</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mpriour]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=834</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[AngularJS is rapidly gaining popularity and favor in the front-end web development community. Several open-source AngularJS wrappers exist for open and closed source web mapping libraries. This session will survey the landscape of existing mapping library wrappers. Wrappers for OpenLayers, Leaflet, d3, Google Maps,  and Esri WebMaps will be examined. Comparisons of the different abilities of these wrappers and the techniques required when using them will be examined. Advantages, strengths, weaknesses, limitations, and "gotchas" will all be examined for the AngularJS interfaces of the different mapping libraries. Attendees should leave the session with an understanding how to best integrate their mapping library of choice within an AngularJS application and how they could help improve these various wrappers.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Open Source Statewide Parcel Mapping Applications</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=835</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kevin.jones]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=835</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I have developed a set of statewide online, mobile and desktop parcel mapping research tools. The tools that I have built are used by government officials and the public.  With tight budgets cuts increased GIS software licensing costs, the counties that I work with have had to use open source alternatives to serve their geospatial data.  I have worked with individual county assessors to develop a statewide webmap portal.  The webmap portal is a one stop location for property webmap research. I have added this technology into the mobile world by introducing a mobile application that is currently offered in the Google Play store. The android gallery uses mobile jquery and allows the users to select the county they want to see data for by clicking the county seal.  I have developed mobile and webmapping solutions for 21 counties and has hyperlinked the portal to an additional 11 counties which developed their own systems.  The public parcel research system webmaps average 1500 hits per month and in some counties have decreased their property research phone calls by up to 50 percent a month.  Using the open source webmap solution has worked great for the public data, but in 2012, I need to make some of that data private and only avaible in house.  I developed an application desktop mapping application called TaxMap. The TaxMap application is based off Microsoft dotnet 4.0 using the dotspatial open source library and is supported on the Windows XP, 7, and 8 environments.  With the TaxMap desktop application, county personal can use popular basemap technology. The TaxMap program supports shapefiles and various raster formats.  Shapefiles can be placed on a common drive where the mapping application is linked to that common drive were the data resides.  The county mapper can setup nightly routines so the TaxMap users view fresh data each day. My website has functionality so county personal can login and download the newest version or the Open Source Desktop TaxMap application, obtain training documentation, watch videos, online quizzes and update their own fusion table webmap.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Earth Observation Monitor: Service-based time-series access and analysis of earth observation data</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=836</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jonas.eberle]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=836</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Earth Observation Monitor project provides automated and operational time-series access and analysis of several earth observation data. A Python-based open-source package, pyEOM, was developed to download, process and analyze time-series data. Several data providers such as NASA Land Processes Distributed Active Archive Center (LPDAAC) for MODIS Land products, NOAA National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for climate station data, and Google Earth Engine for Landsat and MODIS data are connected within pyEOM and can be used to retrieve data for specified areas around the world. Data is being automatically downloaded and processed. In the post-processing part the data can be clipped to the specified area and scaled to original values if needed. 

Time-series analysis tools were integrated to extract further information based on the temporal resolution of the data. Software tools for breakpoint detection in seasonality and trend (BFAST, [1]), trend calculations (greenbrown, [2]), and the derivation of phenological parameters for vegetation data (TIMESAT, [3]) can be executed in pyEOM. The R-packages (BFAST, greenbrown) are executed within Python with the rpy2 module. TIMESAT is started as command line execution. The results are then further processed in Python.

Any of the provided processing tools can be published as OGC Web Processing Service. Integrated and processed data is available with OGC Web Map Service and Web Coverage Service for raster data. Climate station data is available as OGC Sensor Observation Service. Furthermore any dataset is described with ISO-19115 metadata and published within an OGC Catalogue Service for Web. These pyEOM services are based on an open-source software stack including PyWPS for processing services, Mapserver for WMS and WCS, istSOS for sensor observation service, and pycsw for metadata catalogue service. The developments are based on the Multi-Source Data Processing Middleware described in Eberle, et al. (2012, [4]). 

Within this presentation the author will provide an overview of the pyEOM package that is currently under development and describe possibilities for users. Two case scenarios will be presented that make use of the pyEOM services in a web portal and a mobile application [5]. Furthermore future plans to integrate OGC Web Coverage Processing Service were presented. 

[1] = bfast.r-forge.r-project.org
[2] = greenbrown.r-forge.r-project.org
[3] = www.nateko.lu.se/TIMESAT/timesat.asp
[4] = www.mdpi.com/2220-9964/2/3/553
[5] = www.earth-observation-monitor.net]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>836</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 10:53:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Earth Observation, MODIS, Landsat, OGC services, time-series analysis, R, Python]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[end-user, developer]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>MapLoom: A New Web-client With Versioned Editing (GeoGit) Integration</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=837</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[syrusm]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=837</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The need for a user-friendly web-client that enabled effective geospatial data collection, sharing, and collaboration for the ROGUE project motivated us to move away from our GeoExplorer based web-client. Our new web-client, MapLoom, is based on OpenLayers3, AngularJS, and Bootstrap which addresses key shortcomings of GeoExplorer and provides an intuitive and simple interface for performing complex GeoGit operations. The capabilities include per feature and layer history, viewing difference between revisions, merging, conflict resolution, and synchronizing with multiple remotes through the UI. The ability to synchronize a repository with multiple remotes is just one of the reasons why development of GeoGit was the solution to our needs. GeoGit allows distributed versioned editing of geospatial data at a feature level and allows the repositories to be synchronized even in disconnected or reduced connectivity environments.  This talk will cover our experience developing the web-client as well as highlight the use of GeoGit.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>837</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 11:09:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[WebClient, OpenLayers3, GeoGit, GeoExplorer, AngularJS, Versioned Editing,]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Developers, Enduser, and Managers]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Note that the talk is not strictly technical. even though we will make references to AngularJS and OL3, If someone is trying to address their needs for a web-client that is newer, more user-friendly, and more capable than geoexplorer, they can learn from our experience to develop their own client. They can of course fork MapLoom if they choose to as well. We are also the most developed client for GeoGit and as a result, users will essentially getting a user friendly introduction to GeoGit as well. We can expand this talk to be an hour long if you wish. We can spend some time explaining when to use geogit, and when to stay clear of it among many other comments about what else can be exposed to the UI. Attendees will be able to see what GeoGit really gets them as opposed to having to sit through very technical talks and not see it in actions tailored to the end-user. Managers can benefit as well since they will hear our comments about learning curve of AngularJS and state of Ol3.  Please let me know if I can help clarify anything!]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpuf_form_id</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
				<title>Case Study: Developing OpenLayers-based Mobile Applications</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=838</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kevin.zusy]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=838</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Developing an application with the capability to view, collect, and edit geospatial data in connected, limited connectivity, and disconnected environments was a necessity for the ROGUE project. The first version of the application was developed using Cordova/PhoneGap, with everything written in html, css, and javascript, using OpenLayers 2.13 as the mapping library, and jQuery Mobile for the UI. Due to various UI concerns, we decided to implement another version utilizing as much of the native Android API as possible. We also developed a third mobile application using OpenLayers 3 as the mapping library, and Bootstrap for the UI.  This talk will cover our experience developing these three geospatial mobile applications, specifically the differences between the approaches we took and any challenges that we overcame.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

Consider the possibilities: raster, topology, linear referencing, history tracking, web services, overlays, unions, joins, constraints, replication, json, xml, and more!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Creating Custom HTML Elements for Maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=840</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daniel.luxemburg]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=840</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Maps appear all over the web but the core structural language of the web—HTML—does not natively support them. Adding dynamic or interactive maps to a web page or web application can involve complex JavaScript code that is difficult to reuse between contexts.

Web developers are starting to have opportunities to change this. Some newer web development frameworks are designed to support HTML page elements with custom attributes as a way of defining behaviors. These frameworks anticipate web components, an emerging standard for creating fully custom HTML tags. Custom attributes and elements make it possible to effectively expand HTML to include `{my-map}...{/my-map}`.

This talk will demonstrate how to use existing JavaScript map libraries to create flexible, reusable maps that take the form of HTML elements with custom attributes. Looking forward, we'll explore how web components let us take this technique even further and create true custom HTML elements for maps and the display of other geo data.

Crafting custom HTML map elements doesn't just mean making maps a first-class citizen of web page markup, it offers a whole new way to create and share web-based mapping tools between applications and organizations.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>PyWPS - 4 project report</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=841</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jachym.cepicky]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=841</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[PyWPS is one of the first implementations of OGC Web Processing Service (OGC WPS 1.0.0) on the server-side, using Python programming language. Since it’s beginning in 2006 it was offering support for running scripts of GRASS GIS and other popular libraries, such as R, GDAL, Proj4 and other. Users of PyWPS can write their server-side geo-scripts and interface them on the internet using standard WPS interface. 

During last two years, PyWPS development team was discussing new features, users would like to see in this popular OGC WPS Server implementation. Users were missing for example proper support for multiple in- and outputs, advanced logging, more natural serializing, possibility to store big data to external services. PyWPS was never validating properly input data, as long as underlying libraries were able to read them.

Also new versions of nearly everything are at hand - Python 3, GRASS GIS 7 with proper Python support, Fiona, Shapely, no need to write custom code, when OWSLib is around. New formats are now used for sharing of raster and vector data, for example Geo- and TopoJSON. They can be even validated, using json-schema. Python became The geo-scripting language since 2006 (now being slowly replaced by JavaScript). 

Current work on PyWPS 4 is split into several fields: New WSGI interface was written, using Werkzeug. PyWPS has now new core for in- and output data structures (LiteralData and ComplexData). New IOHandler base object can seamlessly switch between file-, stream-like- and in-memory objects.

PyWPS - 4 contains validators of input complex data, which uses four-level of validation (None, mime-type based, “can read GDAL”, schema validation) for XML-based format (like GML) but also for JSON-based formats (like GeoJSON). Literal data are validated on similar way. 
We are going to support MapServer, Geoserver and QGIS MapServer in the future for output complex data management and serving. Data are going to be stored in storages (new abstract class defined), which currently is file system based by now, but can be extend to remote storage (such as FTP or e.g. Dropbox), or to database servers. Possibilities of WPS-T are discussed as well.

PyWPS - 4 will remain the old PyWPS, how our users do like it: small, fast to install and configure, fast to run. But with new features at hand, we will provide you with modern, safe, scalable tool, which you can use to interface the work of yours on the internet.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

				<title>The Manager&#039;s Guide to PostGIS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=842</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Your staff keep talking about this "PostGIS" thing, but what is it? Does anyone (important) else use it? What for?

This talk gives a brief overview of the place of PostGIS in spatial IT architecture, how PostGIS compares to proprietary alternatives, who is using PostGIS, and how organizations transition to open source databases.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Earth Science Data Access and Processing Service for Black Sea (ESPOSS)</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=843</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[vasile.craciunescu]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=843</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Black Sea is one of the world’s basins with the most severe environmental degradation. The environmental problems of the Black Sea are intimately related to the unique characteristics of the marine environment. Efficient analysis and interpretation of EO data (especially satellite imagery) can contribute to a better understanding of these environmental challenges. In spite of the large number of data sources and information services, these are not always accessible to ordinary users. 
In order to meet the users demands of simple interfaces to inspect, download, process and analyze the data, ASRC developed ESPOSS - a web based EO data access and processing application for the Black Sea. The application incorporates geospatial data from various sources (satellite images, in-situ data, model outputs) and serves as a working tool for the scientific community and the relevant decision makers.
It offers services based on Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standards for data retrieval (WMS, WCS, WFS) and server-side processing (WPS). The services were built upon open source solutions such as GeoServer, OpenLayers, GeoExt, PostgreSQL, PyWPS, GDAL. The application is composed of several software modules/services. The modules are split into two categories: server-side modules/services (e.g. data processing, transformation, discovery services) and client side modules - responsible for interaction with the user (Graphical User Interface).
Through ESPOSS, the users have access, among other geospatial data, to a wealth of satellite data coming from various sources and sensors (e.g. MERIS, SMOS, MODIS, AVHRR, SeaWiFS), all related to Black Sea environmental parameters (e.g. Sea Surface Temperature, Chlorophyll concentrations, Sediment related data).]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>843</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 14:07:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[end-users]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
				<title>Spatial in Lucene and Solr</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=844</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[david.w.smiley]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=844</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Apache Lucene is a Java toolkit that provides a rich set of search capabilities such as keyword search, query suggesters, relevancy, and faceting. It also includes a spatial module for searching and sorting with geometric data using either a flat-plane model or a spherical model. The capabilities therein are leveraged to varying degrees by Apache Solr and ElasticSearch--the two leading search servers based on Lucene.

In this talk I’m going to start by briefly covering some core features of this search platform so that the audience appreciates the unique role it plays in the crowded world of information-retrieval. I will then show examples of using some spatial features in Apache Solr such as:
●	indexing points, polygons, and other shapes into a Lucene document
●	filtering search results by a query shape, to include using different search predicates
●	sorting by distance between indexed points and a query point
Next I will review some spatial features in Lucene spatial and ElasticSearch such as:
●	sorting bounding boxes by overlap percentage with a query box
●	aggregating geohash grid counts for heatmaps
The talk will also note the internal architecture and dependencies of Lucene spatial, and discuss a key dependent library called Spatial4j. At the end of the talk I will note some limitations to be aware of, as well as planned improvements. Finally, key advances in geodesic (spherical geometry) information retrieval in Spatial4j will be highlighted.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>844</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 14:16:43</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
				<title>Trusting the Crowd in a Geospatial Crowdsourcing Application</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=845</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[shravan.shah]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=845</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Crowdsourcing as termed by Howe(2009) is known as a way to gather information and data from the general public. In last few years crowdsourcing has become the cheapest and one of the most efficient ways to gather data. With the increased availability of smartphones and smart devices the general public carry a communication device with increasing computational resources, which can also carry a lot of information. With Web 2.0 the access to internet has become simpler and easier.

The crowdsourcing application, we have developed is a rating system that incorporates trust into the application. It works by gathering data of the busyness of hangout places from the crowd, specified in terms of a rating of the busyness of the establishment. The data gathered is shown back to the public using modified ratings and the trustworthiness of those ratings. Ratings are shown in real-time and on a map. The Application was tested in Christchurch, New Zealand, and can be used anywhere.

The end-user platforms on which the application is built includes Android, iOS and the Web.
The tools and technologies include PHP, HTML5, JavaScript, Java, MySQL and PHPMyAdmin.
HTML5 and PHP have been used for designing the main web page which works on any end user platform. JavaScript is used to display base maps from OpenStreetMap and Google servers. PHPMyAdmin is used to manage the MySQL Database. Java was used to program the front end of the application which works in Android and iOS. Data for the places in New Zealand was derived from ‘Zenbu' dataset on 'Koordinates' website.

The application is available on the ‘Google Play Store’ for Android users, and the ‘App Store’ for iOS users. The info windows opens up when a user clicks on the dot. The dots range from small to large, with a small icon indicating a quiet place and the largest icon indicating a busy place. The trust rating shows our confidence in the rating of busyness, using an internal algorithm that produces a result ranging from 0% to 100%.

The website shows the ratings in real time, and can be accessed through any browser. For now it is accessible only in New Zealand, as we only have New Zealand data.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapServer #ProTips</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=846</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[michael.smith]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=846</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MapServer is a fast, flexible and extremely powerful tool for creating dynamic maps for the Web. Underneath the hood, MapServer offers many powerful and advanced features that many users never dig into, and new features are being added constantly. Come learn about some of the more advanced features of MapServer, from heat maps to 3D WFS services to exporting data to GDAL file formats to very complex symbology and labeling. Learn simple and advanced use cases and debugging techniques for some of these advanced features from two presenters with over 20 years combined experience of using MapServer. A live MapServer instance will be used during this presentation (yes we are crazy!).]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>&quot;Do This, and also That: Integrating Open Source tools into traditional GIS shops&quot;</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=848</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[sara]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=848</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This talk is intended for GIS users &amp; managers who may be interested in open source GIS but aren't sure what the advantages to them might be, or who think Open Source GIS is nice in principle but are afraid there's no space for it in their workplace. In general, "Do This, and also That..." wants to address concerns of professionals who aren't sure how or why to make the leap from traditional/proprietary GIS tools into the wide world of Open Source GIS.

Drawing from my own experiences, my goal is to gently present an integrated approach to open source GIS. This is not an "all or nothing" scenario: I want to show the audience how effective workflow solutions can involve both open source GIS as well as "traditional" proprietary GIS they are familiar with.

I will briefly discuss common issues faced by GIS users, and explore the benefits of integrating open-source based workflows alongside proprietary GIS. I will cover use-cases for Leaflet and OpenLayers, OGR2OGR, PostGIS, and QGIS. Each use-case will demo a quick and friendly example of how a particular real-world issue might be addressed by the inclusion of one of these open source options into an existing GIS stack.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>An Automated, Open Source Pipeline for Mass Production of 2 m/px DEMs from Commercial Stereo Imagery</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=849</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dshean]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=849</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We have adapted the NASA Ames Stereo Pipeline (ASP) - a suite of automated, open source, command-line photogrammetry tools originally developed for NASA planetary missions - to process high-resolution stereo satellite imagery of the Earth.  These tools are multithreaded, memory efficient and scalable, which enables processing of “big image data” (e.g., 16-bit panchromatic WorldView images with dimensions ~36000 x 460000 px).  

We have deployed this pipeline on the NASA Pleiades supercomputer to generate ~2 m/px digital elevation models (DEMs) and ~0.5 m/px orthoimages for thousands of WorldView-1/2 along-track stereopairs.  New ASP tools mitigate systematic DEM artifacts and allow for automated, a posteriori DEM coregistration using iterative closest point algorithms.  When existing control data are available (e.g. LiDAR, GPS), automated alignment routines offer sub-meter horizontal and vertical DEM accuracy.

Our research applications focus on ice sheet dynamics in Greenland/Antarctica and ice/snow evolution in the Pacific Northwest.  We have developed an additional collection of tools for DEM analysis, including utilities to produce maps of 3D surface displacement (velocity) vectors and eulerian/lagrangian elevation change.  We present the following case studies to highlight the capabilities of these data and our open source workflow:

-A 57+ DEM timeseries from 2008-2013 for Greenland’s most dynamic outlet glacier, revealing &gt;40 m/yr interannual thinning and large seasonal variability
-Annual DEM mosaics that reveal the ongoing evolution of West Antarctica’s “weak underbelly”, an area roughly the size of New Mexico
-Repeat DEM timeseries for Mt. St. Helen’s showing volcanic dome growth, glacier advance, canopy height, fluvial erosion/deposition, and landslides.

For many applications, DEMs derived from high-resolution satellite imagery are comparable to those derived from airborne LiDAR data, with the advantage of global, on-demand tasking capabilities and reduced costs.  Archived commercial stereo imagery is available at no cost to federal employees or federally-funded researchers, and the tools/methods highlighted here offer an automated, open source alternative to traditional, GUI-based, commercial photogrammetry software packages. 

https://github.com/NeoGeographyToolkit/StereoPipeline]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>849</wp:post_id>

I'm a CUGOS member - I know Aaron wanted to make sure we had solid representation down in PDX.]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
				<title>The Development and Evolution of an open source mapping application within the USG &lt;- Now with More Google Glass</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=850</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[eric.j.finnen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=850</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The United States Government has a history of developing applications using legacy systems and continuing to use brittle software. This approach has managed to minimize data collection, sharing and use of open standards. With this in mind NGA has several groups focused on a rapid, innovative, and open approaches to application development. One of the recent applications developed in this fashion is the Mobile Analytic GEOINT Environment (MAGE),  which evolved from earlier applications that were used for Disaster Response as well as various special events. Each of these earlier applications had their own strengths and weaknesses that were factored in during the development of MAGE. MAGE is built on an open source stack with a mobile and html5 application designed for geospatial data collection, imagery sharing, tracking, and communication. It is designed to be a lightweight, fully portable software stack (MongoDB, NodeJS, Leaflet) that can be placed in front or behind firewalls with ease. It is fully customizable to a wide variety of mission needs so administrators can easily change the data collection parameters. MAGE is fully service enabled allowing easy access to the data via REST requests and returns multiple formats including GeoJSON, KML, and Shapefile to ensure ease of access and sharing. The app has also been ported to Google Glass for field collection and enhanced visualization.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>850</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 17:17:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Disaster Response, MongoDB, , NodeJS, Leaflet, Google Glass]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Developers, managers, end-user]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>OnEarth: NASA’s Boundless Solution to Rapidly Serving Geographic Imagery</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=851</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Joe.T.Roberts]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=851</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[OnEarth is an open source software package that efficiently serves georeferenced raster imagery with virtually zero latency, independent of image size or spatial resolution.  The key to OnEarth’s speed lies in the use of a unique, multi-resolution file format (Meta Raster Format, or MRF) combined with supporting open source software packages such as the Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL) and Apache to serve out images via web service protocols such as Web Map Tile Service (WMTS) and Tiled Web Map Service (TWMS), or visualization formats such as Keyhole Markup Language (KML).  The emphasis on performance and scalability were strong drivers for developing this specialized package versus using existing software.

While OnEarth is currently deployed operationally at several institutions, powering applications across the Earth Science and planetary spectrum, its active development is managed by NASA’s Global Imagery Browse Services (GIBS) project.  The purpose of GIBS is to provide a complementary historical and near real time (NRT) image archive to NASA’s Earth Science data products for a multitude of uses: GIS ingestion, first responder and NRT applications, data search and discovery, decision support, education and outreach.

Released as open source to GitHub in October 2013, NASA is encouraging members of the open source community to participate in the evolution of OnEarth—in the roles of developers, evaluators, and users—as a means to vet and enhance its capabilities.  This leveraging of efforts not only benefits those who intend to use the software for their own endeavors, it effectively contributes back to NASA by strengthening GIBS and promoting the use and understanding of NASA’s vast archive of science imagery and data.  Several tools, including the GIBS reference client, Worldview, will be demonstrated as part of this presentation to illustrate the breadth of application and consistent image access speed across installations.

https://github.com/nasa-gibs/onearth]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Choosing the Right Data Collection Tool</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=852</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rhodges]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=852</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There are many open source data collection tools out there. All of them a little different, either in cost, capabilities, or deployment. The focus of this talk will be helping you to ask the right questions to be sure you quickly determine the subset of tools that will work for you. Whether constrained by budget, hardware, privacy, or features/functionality this talk will help set you on the right path and leave you with idea of which data collection tools will work for you, and which won't.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Connected Cars with PouchDB</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=853</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[norman.barker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=853</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Connected cars are everywhere and writing apps for connected cars is an emerging space. OpenXC is an open JSON data API for Ford cars that enables developers to write custom apps for telemetry data in real time, this includes geographic location.

Bandwidth and connectivity in a car is limited however and as such an app needs to be written to be offline first. 

This talk discusses the difficulties of connected cars and how to overcome this big data problem with PouchDB, CouchDB, Leaflet and Google Chrome Applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>CS-Map - coordinate system libraries</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=854</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[norman.barker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=854</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[CS-Map is often used as a reference but has not been as widely adopted as proj4. This presentation describes how CS-Map has been used in a distributed geospatial database for big data. 

The presentation describes the benefits of CS-Map, in particular its whole earth support and also it disadvantages, primarily it is process locked.

The aim of the presentation is to demonstrate that having more than one coordinate system library is a good thing and to encourage development of coordinate system libraries.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Defining &quot;Home&quot;</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=855</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rhodges]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=855</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[How do we define where we live? How about where no people live? How do we define regions to solve problems that go beyond watersheds and do not conform to political boundaries: regions based on any mix of metrics based on culture, climate, geography, space-time, and more? What have been some of the consequences of making decisions bounded by national borders or latitude and longitude? This talk will cover both the philosophy that drives these questions, some processes that have been used to address this in the past, and a few of the exciting open source apps and tools out there to help people remap their world.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Spatial-Temporal Prediction of Climate Change Impacts using geopredict, scikit-learn and GDAL</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=856</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[perrygeo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=856</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As the field of climate modeling continues to mature, we must anticipate the practical implications of the climatic shifts predicted by these models. In this talk, I’ll show how we apply the results of climate change models to predict shifts in agricultural zones across the western US. I will outline the use of the Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL) and Scikit-Learn (sklearn) to perform supervised classification, training the model using current climatic conditions and predicting the zones as spatially-explicit raster surfaces across a range of future climate scenarios. Finally, I’ll present a python module (geopredict) which provides an API to optimize and streamline the process of spatial classification and regression problems.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The open-source stack behind the Forest Planner</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=857</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[perrygeo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=857</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ecotrust’s Forest Planner is a decision support tool for private landowners in the Pacific Northwest. The Forest Planner gives small landowners a free tool to visualize and explore alternative forestry management scenarios for their properties. The pieces of technology have been around for a few years but the cost and expertise to put it all together meant that it was inaccessible to the users who needed it most. In this talk, I’ll outline the conceptual framework of the Forest Planner and highlight the open source technology stack that powers it. Specifically, we’ll show how the following components come together to form the Forest Planner:

* Geospatial Data Abstraction Library
* Pandas and Numpy
* SciPy
* Open-FVS and Growth-Yield-Batch
* OpenLayers
* Madrona and GeoDjango
* Rasterstats
* Harvest-Scheduler and Cost Model
* PostGIS

Instead of a deep-dive on any particular topic, this talk will demonstrate a high-level architecture for a complex decision support system and share some lessons learned for those interested in building similar tools.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>857</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 19:56:35</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
				<title>Building GIS, Decision Support, and Location Intelligence Applications Using Open Source Tools</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=860</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nmceachen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=860</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There is a growing need for GIS, decision support, and location intelligence applications. Maps can be more than just static and read only artifacts. Rather, they can be fully integrated within an application to allow users to interact directly with their data. Furthermore, user interfaces can be created that abstract the complexity of GIS and provide non-GIS professionals with a user interface metaphor for their business domain. Open source GIS software tools, such as OpenLayers, GeoServer, and PostGIS, are incredibly powerful and are often viable alternatives to commercial GIS tools. However, building an enterprise-class geospatial application using these tools is a daunting task. We will demonstrate how to quickly integrate open source GIS tools with an open source data management framework to build GIS and decision support applications. By using ontologies to model geographical locations, called geo-ontologies, we will demonstrate how to build location intelligence applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Building development environments using Vagrant</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=861</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mikael.blomberg]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=861</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Building development environments using Vagrant

During Oskari.org development we noticed releases usually where delayed due to environment differences. Our desktop and server environments are quite different. We believe there should be no differences between the production and development environments. In our research we discovered Vagrant, which utilizes Virtualbox for creating virtual environments. It was a perfect solution and we wondered into the world of DevOps. We noticed our lack of automation and began our search for a good Configuration Management tool. Our research showed many promising alternatives and we ended up choosing Ansible. Armed with Vagrant and Ansible we began to automate our development environment in a reproducible way. This talk is about our journey into DevOps and why you should join us!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Seven ways of injecting Python to QGIS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=862</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jakob]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=862</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will enlighten the novice Python QGIS user with different ways of running Python code in QGIS without the need of building a QGIS Python plugin. Any intermediate to advanced QGIS user could start writing Python scripts for automating, customizing and extending QGIS, making their daily workflow an easier and more fun task to complete.
1. Python through the QGIS Python Console and Script editor:
This would be the most obvious place for PyQGIS newcomers. The console and editor comes with syntax highlighting, autocomplete and easy integration to QGIS.
2. Scriptrunner: 
A very handy plugin for running Python more advanced scripts in QGIS by using a meta method 
run_script(iface). Using the script runner gives you a plugin kind of feeling when running scripts.
3. Extending the Expression engine:
Placing a startup.py in your .QGIS2 Python folder with a @qgsfunction(0, "Python") attribute. Methods from the startup.py can be called from the Expression Engine. An example is shown adding the name of the current user, to a label on a Print Composer composition.
4. Run script on project event -open, close and save:
Found under Projects Properties &gt; Macros. You may want to validate if a certain table is open, and notify the user if it is not, when opening or saving a QGIS project.
5. Python in QGIS Actions:
Extend your QGIS actions with Python code. 
6. Python Init function:
An overseen and very powerful feature in QGIS when creating new features. Not only can you validate and programmatically edit your attribute input, but you can also process the newly digitalized geometry. An example is shown creating rectangular oil tanks with predefined dimension.
7. Processing Framework:
Scripting methods from the Processing Framework is especially useful when you need to loop or run a batch of commands from the Processing Framework.
Live demo of several of the above methods of using Python in QGIS will be shown.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Responsive Interactivity: Toward User-centered Adaptive Map Experiences</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=863</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jczaplew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=863</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In recent years, the web design community has moved quickly to accommodate the various devices and methods for accessing web content. The FOSS4G and wider development community have responded to this paradigm of adapting the layout of content to scale to the device of the user by creating and leveraging tools such as Leaflet and D3. However, there remains a lack of knowledge, understanding, and conversation about what it truly means to create a map experience that meets the present needs and expectations of the user. Designing an adaptive map should go beyond simply fitting it into a responsive layout. User variables, such as the mode of interaction and location-based needs, raise map-specific UI design questions that this community is uniquely positioned to answer.

This talk will explore what it could mean cartographically and experientially to adapt all aspects of the map experience to the needs of the user using principles already embraced in other communities. Our goal is to provoke a wider discussion of how we, as a community, can work toward these objectives. Regardless of expertise level, anyone who is involved with the creation of interactive web maps has inevitably come across the problems associated with, and will benefit from involvement in this conversation.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Needs of Earth Observation data access in the frame of &quot;Big data&quot;</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=865</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jonas.eberle]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=865</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The available amount of earth observation data is increasing day by day. Especially with new data from Landsat 8 and furthermore new data in the scope of several terabytes daily from the new and upcoming ESA Sentinel satellites will be available and can be analyzed by users. Of course not anybody needs the global dataset, but scientists and users need to find ways to extract data in a specific time frame for their area of interest. In that case it is not enough to provide access to data files, users need services to directly extract just the explicit needed data within a space-time data cube. 

A possible solution for this issue is the OGC Web Coverage Processing Service (WCPS) specification allowing to process such multi-dimensional data in a service-based environment. This specification is available within the petascope component of rasdaman, an open source tool to manage multi-dimensional data. Beside data extraction on a spatial and temporal parameter, the data can be processed by the service, e.g. by calculating spectral indices or specific band combinations. For example, the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) can be calculated from the service instead of downloading both spectral bands and calculating the index by the user itself. This reduces the amount of data transfer to the user and saves time to compute the index if the service is provided on a high performance server. Results of an independent test of the WCPS provided with petascope and rasdaman working with MODIS vegetation and Landsat time-series data were presented. 

Another stunning solution is provided by Google with the Google Earth Engine. Although this is not open source software, Google provides data access and processing capabilities for free. Either in a web-based JavaScript programming environment or with a Python API users can process the complete Landsat archive and several MODIS products on Google’s server infrastructure. The processed data can automatically be downloaded and further processed on our own computers.  Therefore Google Earth Engine provides a set of functions for data processing and analysis. 

In this talk we would like to present what is needed to make the access of “big” Earth Observation raster data as easy as possible for scientists, users, and service providers. Two current possibilities how to access and pre-process such big data either through OGC WCPS service or through other data providers engines with the example of Google Earth Engine were presented.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>865</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-14 23:25:01</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[OGC, big data, earth observation, raster, web coverage processing service, data access, google earth engine]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Embedded maps made easy - Oskari.org platform</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=866</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jani.kylmaaho]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=866</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[How to easily embed a map on any website?
How to use data from WFS services with complex schema in a browser?
How to use statistical data to create a thematic map in 1 minute?
How to find out how many people live within 1km of a given set of POI?

Oskari.org is your Open Source tool to answer the above questions. A wealth of data are available from existing national, international and crowdsourced SDIs through services with standard protocols. The Oskari.org platform provides tools to read and process information from WMS, WMTS, WFS, CSW and JSON-stat data sources.

For a skilled person, it is effortless to set up an OpenLayers map and customize the application to suit the use case. However, this is not possible for the majority of those who need to put maps on websites. Once set up, Oskari.org eliminates the need to write code. Users can make thematic maps, perform spatial analysis and create embedded maps of the results. Especially the embedded maps  can be made very simple to use, even for those not familiar with GIS systems or principles.

Possible use cases include, but are not limited to, eGovernment services, map-assisted interactive feedback and data maintenance systems, visualization of statistical information as well as geospatial analysis in a browser.

On a technical note, Oskari.org platform features a modular and extensible map application framework based on JavaScript libraries on browser side. Common OSGeo components, such as PostGIS, GeoServer and GeoTools are utilized on the server side.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoServer On Steroids</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=867</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[simone.giannecchini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=867</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Setting up a GeoServer can sometimes be deceptively simple. However, going from proof of concept to production requires a number of steps to be taken in order to optimize the server in terms of availability, performance and scalability. The presentation will show how to get from a basic setup to a battle ready, rock solid installation by showing the ropes an advanced user already mastered. The topics that will be covered in details include: 

- Optimize vector and raster data for the deep multi-resolution displays typical of web GIS 
- Optimize styling to provide a good balance between map navigability and performance, identifying common performance pitfalls in the styling options 
- Setting up caching with GWC for the background layers, identify layers and situations that are not suitable for caching 
- Defend against peak hour load by setting service limits and using the control-flow extension
- Using the monitoring extension to control the server in production and identify sources of trouble (long request, clients making too many/too heavy requests, layers and services used the most that could use more tuning attention)
- Solutions for clustering GeoServer and GeoWebCache 
- Challenges in scaling beyond the few hundreds concurrent requests, and solutions to get there 

The presentation will end with real world examples of enterprise deployments of GeoServer implemented by the author as well as its colleagues at GeoSolutions during the years.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoServer for Spatio-temporal Data Handling With Examples For MetOc And Remote Sensing</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=868</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[simone.giannecchini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=868</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will provide detailed information on how to ingest and configure SpatioTemporal in GeoServer to be served using OGC services, with examples from WMS and WCS services.
 
Topics covered are as follows:
- Discussion over existing data formats and how to preprocess them for best serving with GeoServer
- Configuring SpatioTemporal raster and vector data in GeoServer 
- Serving SpatioTemporal raster and vector data with OGC Services
- Tips and techniques to optimize performance and allow maximum exploitation of the available data 

The attendees will be provided with the basic knowledge needed to preprocess and ingest the most common spatiotemporal data from the MetOc and Remote Sensing field for serving via GeoServer.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Processing Data In GeoServer With Rendering Transformations, WPS Processes And SQL Views</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=869</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[andrea.aime]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=869</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will provide the attendee with an introduction to data processing in GeoServer by means of WPS, rendering transformations and SQL views, describing real applications and how these facilities were used in them. We'll start with the basic WPS capabilities, showing how to build processing request based on existing processes and how to build new processes leveraging scripting languages, and introducing unique GeoServer integration features, showing how processing can seamlessly integrate directly in the GeoServer data sources and complement existing services. We'll also show how to integrate on the fly processing in WMS requests, achieving high performance data displays without having to pre-process the data in advance, and allowing the caller to interactively choose processing parameters. While the above shows how to make GeoServer perform the work, the processing abilities of spatial databases should not be forgotten, so we’ll show how certain classes of processing can be achieved directly in the database. At the end the attendee will be able to easily issue WPS requests both for Vectors and Rasters to GeoServer through the WPS Demo Builder, enrich SLDs with on-the-fly rendering transformations and play with SQL views in order to create dynamic layers.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapStore, create, save and share mashups</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=870</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[simone.giannecchini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=870</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MapStore has been developed to create, save, and share in a simple and intuitive way maps and mashups created by selecting content from the server such as Google Maps, OpenStreetMap, MapQuest, or specific servers provided by your organization or by a third party.

MapStore consists of two main components MapManager and GeoStore, respectively front-end  and back-end. MapManager allows through a unique interface to create, modify, delay and search on maps definition as well as generate a univoque link to embed a map in an external website, share your own maps with the others, all this can be made by interacting with GeoStore.MapManager supports both authentication and access policy definition for the protection of the maps managed by GeoStore.  GeoStore implements a flexible infrastructure developed with Java Enterprise technology to create, manage, browse and search maps definitions. GeoStore integrates the management of the authentication and authorization following The Role based Access Control paradigm (RBAC) for the protection against unwanted accesses. The GeoStore standard storage mechanism is  constituted by a DBMS: Oracle and PostgreSQL are supported as well as the Open Source and high performance H2 pure Java embedded DBMS 

The newly developed native Android MapStore Mobile version will be introduced and discussed along with its development roadmap.

The presentation will give the audience an extensive overview of the MapStore functionalities for the creation of mapping portals.  Eventually, a range of GeoSolutions case studies of MapStore will be presented.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mapping in GeoServer with SLD and CSS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=871</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[andrea.aime]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=871</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Various software can style maps and generate a proper SLD document for OGC compliant WMS like GeoServer to use. However, in most occasions, the styling allowed by the graphical tools is pretty limited and not good enough to achieve good looking, readable and efficient cartographic output. For those that like to write their own styles CSS also represents a nice alternatives thanks to its compact-ness and expressiveness.
Several topics will be covered, providing examples in both SLD and CSS for each, including: mastering multi-scale styling, using GeoServer extensions to build common hatch patterns,  line styling beyond the basics, such as cased lines, controlling symbols along a line and the way they repeat, leveraging TTF symbol fonts and SVGs to generate good looking point thematic maps, using the full power of GeoServer label lay-outing tools to build pleasant, informative maps on both point, polygon and line layers, including adding road plates around labels, leverage the labelling subsystem conflict resolution engine to avoid overlaps in stand alone point symbology, blending charts into a map, dynamically transform data during rendering to get more explicative maps without the need to pre-process a large amount of views. The presentation aims to provide the attendees with enough information to master SLD/CSS documents and most of GeoServer extensions to generate fast, appealing, informative and readable maps.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Advanced Security With GeoServer</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=872</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[andrea.aime]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=872</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The presentation will provide an introduction to GeoServer own authentication and authorization subsystems. We’ll cover the supported authentication protocols, such as from basic/digest authentication and CAS support, check through the various identity providers, such as local config files, database tables and LDAP servers, and how it’s possible to combine the various bits in a single comprehensive authentication tool, as well as providing examples of custom authentication plugins for GeoServer, integrating it in a home grown security architecture.
We’ll then move on to authorization, describing the GeoServer pluggable authorization mechanism and comparing it with proxy based solution, and check the built in service and data security system, reviewing its benefits and limitations.
Finally we’ll explore an advanced authentication tool called GeoFence, and see how it can plug into GeoServer to provide graphical configuration abilities for use complex authorization rules over data and OGC services, taking into account spatial filters, attribute filters, attribute hiding as well as cropping raster data to areas of interest. Finally we’ll show how using LDAP both GeoFence and GeoServer can use a common users database, simplifying administrators job, and provide some real world examples.]]></content:encoded>
