	<item>
				<title>How to tell stories and engage an audience with maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=922</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[andrew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=922</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Maps and stories go together like two peas in a pod. Why is that and how do we take advantage of it? Through my work at CartoDB, I have been able to think deeply about the role of storytelling for today's map makers. Here, I will talk about the insights we have gained through teaching CartoDB users, building libraries such as Torque and Odyssey.js, and creating innovative maps online. Some of my maps have included FOSS4G award winners (NYCHenge and PLUTO Data Tour) as well as dozens of unique and interesting experiments to combine interaction and multimedia with maps or trying to find the limits of what we call a map. If we plan to keep mapping relevant and exciting, it is important that we keep finding the exciting new ways to bend technology to engage people. The map has an interesting future over the coming years and here I will talk about some of the ways we should expect it to go and what it means for us as geospatial software developers.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>schedule_day</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Open Source Social Media Aggregation and Geolocating for Emergency Management</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=923</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dan.king]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=923</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This paper is a case study of the social media situational awareness project organized by the agencies of the Puget Sound region of the Pacific Northwest.

The goal of the project is to capture, analyze and map social media using open source tools. The desired end result is improved situation awareness through a clearer operational picture which in turn assists in a providing a more targeted response.

The open source software chosen for this project was SwiftRiver from Ushahidi. SwiftRiver gathers social media by keyword and runs the content through a natural language processor which performs semantic analysis to add context, including recognition of people, organizations and, most importantly, location.

The Puget Sound is an actively seismic region and is prone to massive earthquakes, such as the 1700 magnitude 9 Cascadia earthquake. The next such earthquake in the region will cause widespread casualties and damage. 

Inevitably, when the ‘Big One’ hits the public will turn to social media to report what is happening in their area. The collective information has the capacity to assist in assessment of problems and direct resources where needed most.

The project stack includes SwiftRiver, PHP, OpenLayers and GeoServer as well as complementary iOS and Android mobile applications that allow trusted sources to report addition critical information during an incident.

The open nature of social media provided numerous opportunities to test the platform. Since deploying in May of 2013 we tracked major Puget Sound festivals and gatherings based on Twitter keyword searches, including:
-	Tacoma Freedom Fair (July 2013)
-	SeaFair weekend (August 2013)
-	Seattle Seahawks Super Bowl victory parade (February 2014)

In addition to local events we were able to test the system on real-world incidents around the globe, including
-	Oklahoma Moore tornado (May 2013)
-	Washington D.C. Navy Yard shooting (September 2013)
-	Kenya Westgate Mall hostage siege (September 2013)

The first regional disaster since the launch came in late March of 2014 during the Washington State Oso landline. The paper continues with analysis of the keywords searched, content gathered and methods for aggregating and disseminating the information to emergency responders at the scene.

The paper concludes with a list of challenges encountered, problems solved and next steps, including:
- Training the natural language processor to recognize locations of common landmarks in the Puget Sound.
- Harnessing the small but relevant percentage of tweets with geolocation coordinates.
- Harness the power of D3JS and GeoJSON to produce interactive drill-down map visualizations.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Priming the pump: how CartoDB creates innovative mappers</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=924</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[andrew]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=924</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the past three years CartoDB users have continuously generated unique, innovative, and interesting maps online. It would not be possible without recent progress in open source tools, but also it comes from a careful attempt to empower people to be amazing mappers. In this talk, I'll speak about how we enable people with open source tools through novel education approaches, outreach the often resembles collaboration, and by putting novel techniques directly into the hands of our users. One of the guiding principles at CartoDB is to make using open source geospatial so easy that people can make maps in minutes. We often skip the discussion of projections, data formats, and libraries in favor of letting people create maps from the first minute. After they are making maps, we fill their knowledge through online training, open community forums, and rapid prototype development. Here, I'll talk about how these approaches have led to an amazing new open source user community.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>3D slippy map with three.js</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=925</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jarle.pedersen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=925</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We will demonstrate the use of WMS and WCS as input to three.js for rendering an interactive 3D-model in the browser, based on actual data. Our extension of three.js, (WxS.threejs) takes several inputs, the boundingbox being the simplest. WMS-service, WCS-service, LAYERS and many, many other variables can be set either via the URL or predefined in a quick and easy setup. Further, we wish to introduce the idea of using cached WMS as an input. We’ve prepared a framework that is ready for consuming WMTS, rendering tiled 3D-models that are stitched together. The goal is to implement a slippy map in 3D. This is an open invitation to all hungry hackers who wish to join us in tapping the potential.

Original article:
http://labs.kartverket.no/wcs-i-threejs/
Example:
http://labs.kartverket.no/threejs/wxs.three.html
Github:
https://github.com/jarped/wxs.threejs]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Infowindow evolution: open source contributions to a long history in GIS user interface</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=926</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jmedina]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=926</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Infowindows have a long history in the realm of mapping. From ESRI to Google, through OpenLayers and Leaflet, infowindows have long been a part of our mapping experience. Starting before MapQuest, we will talk about the evolution of these unique data communication tools. In particular, we will focus on the more recent open source contributions to the understanding of how infowindows can work within a map-based interface. What can we learn from the progress of infowindows and where do they fit in a mobile dominated world? As data communication through thematic, dynamic and responsive maps where do we still need infowindows and popups? Even at CartoDB, our custom infowindows have gone through numerous stages in an evolution that still isn't complete. Come hear our thoughts on the future of these strange elements.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>From the APIs to the web client, how to build a client side GIS infrastructure</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=927</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jmedina]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=927</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At CartoDB we have built an innovative GIS interface that runs entirely in your browser. Within the tool we have packed in table and map interfaces, data management tools, map styling wizards, authoring tools, publishing tools, and a host of other features. Our front end application is a custom JavaScript library that extends our public CartoDB.js library. It includes the account, map and data management interfaces and wraps together Leaflet and a host of other open source libraries in a Backbone application. Here we will detail the architecture of the platform and tell you what we have learned from building an open source GIS interface.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Empowering people, popularizing open source, and building a business</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=928</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jatorre]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=928</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Vizzuality went from a data communications consulting company to the creator of one of today's most popular online mapping frameworks, CartoDB. Four years ago, we recognized a major problem in open source geospatial tools, they were still prohibitively difficult to use to creating dynamic, interactive, and beautiful online maps. That was when we decided to build CartoDB, a mix of existing open source software such as PostGIS and our own new code. Each account on CartoDB represents a new PostGIS enabled database, a new user of libraries such as Leaflet, and we hope, a long-time supporter of open source. In this talk, I'll present on how we are building a new and quickly growing community around open source geospatial. I'll talk about our plans for the future and how we plan to support open source for many years to come.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The unrelenting progress of design in open source</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=929</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[saleiva]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=929</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Open source geospatial is in an Enlightenment era regarding design; many teams are breaking away from tradition and embracing simple, clean, and usable interfaces. For a long time though, open source geospatial software, and geospatial software in general, seemed to pay little attention to the knowledge of the design community. Here, I will discuss why design has taken a backseat for such a long history and what is suddenly changing that brings it to the forefront. I will also talk some about the design decisions that have gone into the CartoDB user interface and many of the mapping options we help our users find. This talk will focus both on the history of design in open source geospatial software and where it is heading in the future. We will also talk about how design itself is inherently open and how we are working to improve open source software design through our own contributions and through this discussion of our process.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>929</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-15 11:39:48</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
				<title>Exposing NASA&#039;s Earth Observations</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=930</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ryan.a.boller]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=930</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The satellites which comprise NASA's Earth Observing System (EOS) have a long history of capturing rich datasets with global coverage over extended periods of time.  While the data itself is rich (and open!), it can be a daunting task for uninitiated users to find suitable datasets, learn the data format, and subsequently find interesting phenomena.  Even for those who are familiar with the data, it can be a time consuming process.   But thanks to the proliferation and maturity of open source geospatial software, NASA has been able to build an imagery ingest pipeline, open source tiled imagery server, and open source, web-based mapping client to encourage exploration and discovery of NASA datasets.  This talk will describe how NASA is building these capabilities through the Global Imagery Browse Services (GIBS) and Worldview client, demonstrate how others are building upon them, and show what it takes to integrate NASA imagery into clients using the GIBS API.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Managing public data on GitHub: Pay no attention to that git behind the curtain</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=931</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[landonreed]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=931</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Atlanta Regional Commission (ARC) continuously solicits feedback on transportation data from local government partners.  Historically, this process has taken the form of lots of markings on plotted maps with immeasurable amounts of manual work on the tail end to organize and interpret this feedback.  Many tools developed specifically for this process today often fall short of the needs of agencies (such as geospatial presentation and tracking comments), yet the cost to develop or implement custom software is generally out of reach for government agencies.

This presentation introduces a case study of the process to develop geospatial collaboration tools for managing transportation data directly hosted on GitHub pages (currently in development at http://atlregional.github.io/plan-it/ and http://atlregional.github.io/fc-review/).  This approach was partially inspired by GitHub’s recent features additions that make collaborating on geospatial data simple and elegant.  

Because these data span both functional and jurisdictional divisions, many of the greatest challenges have been project management related --- coordinating stakeholder feedback and project requirements.  However, by utilizing the existing git/GitHub infrastructure, many of these requirements can be managed cost effectively.  Moreover, the framework allows for direct integration with other application environments via the GitHub API and GDAL Tools, ensuring that local modifications to project data are committed back to the data repository.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Dynamic mapping on the web: building a scalable service for thousands of companies</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=932</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jsantana]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=932</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At CartoDB is an open source stack that includes PostgreSQL, PostGIS, Mapnik and Leaflet. The hosted version enables thousands of users to make new and interesting maps everyday. With some of those users including Al Jazeera America, Twitter, and even online gaming platforms, we aren’t scaling for one popular webpage but for thousands of different ones each day. On top of that, maps aren’t constrained to a single filter, single style, or to a predefined zoom, CartoDB allows users to access the full power of a dynamic database from the front end. In this talk, I’ll present the architecture decisions we have implemented that make it possible to turn PostgreSQL and PostGIS into components of a powerful real-time data visualization tool. These decisions cut straight through the CartoDB software stack, from PostgreSQL and PostGIS through our caching and tile services, and up through to our CartoDB.js library. We’ll talk about our on-demand tiling service, our caching strategy, and our implementation of the novel data format for Torque. Each of these areas has enabled our users to make user of entirely open source tools to create maps and services that scale, remain fast, and are beautiful.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>ScribeUI: MapServer Mapfile management made easy</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=933</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jlacroix]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=933</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Anyone who has tried to create great looking maps for a large dataset such as OpenStreetMap knows how daunting of a task that can be. Scribe is the solution to this painstaking task. This presentation will introduce this new way to not only edit, but mostly to manage, mapfiles. No matter how much data you have, how many mapfiles or the complexity of your symbology, it will help you sort out the essential by removing the iterative part of the process. Getting rid of all of this error prone copy-paste as well! After nearly two years of development and another great Google Summer of Code, the tool is greater than ever and ready to be reviewed by the community.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Migrating web services and applications to an OpenGeo environment</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=934</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bob.bistrais]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=934</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the past several years, the Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems (MEGIS) has created and hosted GIS web services and applications using Open Source solutions.  In 2013, MEGIS began evaluating migration of our services and applications to an OpenGeo Suite environment, and moving our PHP-based viewer applications to GeoExt-based ones.  This presentation will discuss that process, including reasons for migration and reasons for choosing OpenGeo Suite, and R&amp;D requirements for moving to that environment.  We will also look at the new web services and applications that have been developed since we migrated, and discuss successes, limitations, and issues still to be resolved in the new environment.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Complete Multi-Modal Carpooling and Route Planning Solution</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=935</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jlacroix]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=935</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sustainable transportation is a nice idea but can be hard to apply in real life to your daily commute to work or school. For many it involves multiple transportation modes and it can be a challenge to combine the time tables from multiple sources in order to plan the most efficient route. We took the challenge and worked with stakeholders from the Saguenay region to build a portal that provides a simple yet really optimal way to get around in both urban and rural areas be it by bus, bike, share taxi and even carpooling or by combining multiple modes in order to promote sustainable transport. The system built on pgRouting, PostGIS, Django and OpenLayers3 allows users to register offers or search for the best available match in existing offers, comparing and combining as well with city buses and all your other favorite transportation options. It is a solution that will help and inspire city planners or city transport organizations to bring all their transportation systems together to get people moving the right way.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Extracting geographic data from Wikipedia</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=936</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[hal]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=936</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A large fraction of Wikipedia's millions of articles include geographic references. This makes Wikipedia a potentially rich source for themed, curated geographic datasets. But the free form nature of Wikipedia's markup language presents some technical challenges. I'll walk through the Wikipedia API, show how to get to the various places where spatial info might be found, and show some blind alleys I've followed. I'll close with a case study of using Wikipedia to drive a map-based iOS app.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapMint: The 100% service-oriented GIS platform</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=937</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nicolas.bozon]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=937</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MapMint is an comprehensive task manager for publishing webmapping applications. It is a robust open source geospatial platform allowing the user to organize, edit, process and publish spatial data to the Internet. MapMint includes a complete administration tool for MapServer and a simple user interfaces to create mapfiles visually. Its use does not require any coding and most of the mapfile parameters are supported, so the user can fully focus on the map features and not on its source code. The latter is generated using various WPS requests which are using the user's data and settings as input.

MapMint is based on the extensive use of OGC standards and automates WMS, WFS, WMT-S and WPS. Most of the MapMint core functions are run through WPS requests which are calling general or geospatial web services (vector and raster operations, mapfiles creation, spatial analysis and queries and much more). MapMint server-side is built on top of ZOO-Project, MapServer and GDAL and its numerous WPS services are written in Python and JavaScript. MapMint client-side is based on OpenLayers and Jquery and provides user-friendly to create, publish and view maps. 

MapMint architecture and main features will be introduced in this presentation, and its modules (dashboard, data, maps and apps) will be described with an emphasis on the OGC standards and OSGeo software they are using. Some short case studies and examples will finally illustrate some of the the key functionalities.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Using FOSS Tools, UAVs and Linear Referencing to Better Manage Federal Levee Data</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=938</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[will.l.breitkreutz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=938</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) is responsible for thousands of miles of levees in the United States.  Over time the agency has developed a very specific way of evaluating levee systems and relationships between their constituent parts.  This approach has served USACE well, at least until having to coordinate our internal data structures with additional data managed by other agencies or programs who potentially treat levees in very different ways.  Solving this requirement led to a new approach being developed inside the USACE National Levee Database program referred to as Reaches.  Based on linear referencing, the Reaches approach combines interactive creation of linear event themes, a graphical linear reference data editor, and user driven symbolization of the data within a single comprehensive web interface.  Using a combination of OpenLayers, GeoExt on the client side and Oracle SDO, MapServer and GeoTools on the server, it is optimized both for speed and flexibility, putting the power of the linear referencing approach into the hands of a range of technical and non-technical users.   This presentation presents an architectural overview of the system and how FOSS applications were leveraged during development of Reaches.
 
The ability to manage data with a new level of flexibility and interactivity is supported in some cases by our new unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery pipeline.  Flying imagery from altitudes only in the hundreds of feet give us images with resolution down to inches.  By stitching these images into geotiff mosaic composites then processing into individual MBTiles databases using TileMill, we get a new level of perspective on construction projects and any other ground conditions, allowing for monitoring change over time at a convenience and price our agency has not previously had available.  The full capability of this imagery is brought to light by our custom tile services that are generated down to zoom level 24. This presentation will show how by pairing the new imagery capabilities with the Reaches tools for collecting and storing data, our non-technical users now have access to tools and data normally reserved for the GIS/RS team.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>NGDS – a community experiment in FOSS</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=939</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[christy.caudill]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=939</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The National Geothermal Data System (NGDS) is a distributed system designed to provide online access to geothermal-related data from a network of data providers. The network is based on open standards and protocols adopted for the US Geoscience Information Network (USGIN) that facilitate public access to interoperable, digital earth science data, while preserving ownership and management of data. Development of NGDS focused on OSGS solutions in implementation and user experience to minimize reliance on proprietary software and lower the barriers to viewing or hosting web services.  NGDS serves to bring developers and new users into the project as a community experience, with all code available on GitHub (http://github.com/ngds) to support development of custom OS applications.

CKAN (http://ckan.org/) FOSS was chosen as the development springboard for NGDS, with OS components like Apache SOLR and Tomcat, PostGIS, and GeoServer in the NGDS extension build.  A packaged NGDS software stack (NIAB, Node-In-A-Box) allows users an easy installation of their own UI and data management system to become a node, release data using interoperable and shareable standards, host web services, or harvest metadata to become a community catalog. NGDS is built as a distributed network of data providers based on standard interfaces and interchange formats; nodes may use the NIAB software stack or any other software front-end as long as ISO metadata standards and other specified protocols are supported. The AZGS node uses a custom OS application for metadata management and validation, developed with Node.js, Apache CouchDB, and a Django front-end.

Standardized data accessible through web services gives developers the opportunity to create applications based on NGDS. We encourage user development on the NGDS site with a Data Developers page giving examples. The NGDS site links to http://lab.usgin.org  which is a test bed for new applications, user experiences, information on OS software, and blogs created by the development community. Applications already built on top of the NGDS use OpenLayers, GeoExt, ExtJS, JavaScript, Apache SOLR and CouchDB, GDAL/OGR and Leaflet.

The NGDS relies on OSGS and encourages its use by providing links on the NGDS project site accompanied by how-to videos and text. USGIN, specifying standards on which NGDS is built, supports http://lab.usgin.org and http://tech.usgin.org to foster OSS development and use. We hope that the user community is empowered to carry on with innovative development and of use of OSGS through this project.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>939</wp:post_id>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>ZOO-Project 1.4.0: news about the Open WPS Platform</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=940</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gerald.fenoy]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=940</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ZOO-Project is an Open  Source Implementation of the OGC Web Processing Service (WPS), it was released under a MIT/X-11 style license and is currently in incubation at OSGeo. It provides a WPS compliant developer-friendly framework to easilly create and chain WPS Web services. 
This talk give a brief overview of the platform and summarize new capabilities and enhancement available in the 1.4.0 release.
A brief introduction to WPS and a summary of the Open Source project history with its direct link with FOSS4G will be presented. Then an overview of the ZOO-Project will serve to introduce new functionalities and concepts available in the 1.4.0 release and highlight their interrests for applications developpers and users. Then, examples of concrete services chain use will illustrate the way ZOO-Project can be used to build complete applications in a flexible way by using the service chain concept, creating new service by implementing intelligent chain of service through ZOO-API but also by taking advantage of the publication using OGC standards. Various use of OSGeo softwares, such as GDAL, GEOS, PostGIS, pgRouting, as WPS services through the ZOO-Project will be illustrated by applications presentation.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>940</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-15 12:30:30</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[OGC,WPS,GDAL,GRASS,ZOO-Project,LibreOffice,Web Processing,Web Applications]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[all]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Co-Autor: 
Venkatesh Raghavan, Osaka City University]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpuf_form_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[268]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>topic</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[WPS]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Multidimensional Map Painting: Mannahatta2409.org</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=941</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kfisher]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=941</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Typically, interactive geospatial web applications require user input in the form of vector operations -- creating and editing points, lines, and polygons. But what if users could geospatially paint, rather than draw? This presentation will tell the story of our development of a "geospatial photoshop" user interface that allows users to paint on top of a map, and show how this painting interface stores and retrieves multidimensional raster cell values on the fly, feeding complex client-side environmental performance calculations.

Mannahatta 2409 (http://mannahatta2409.org) is a new web application that enables any user to develop and share their visions for Manhattan in the future, with reference to its pre-development ecology (http://welikia.org) and current natural and built landcover. Students, urban planners and architects, and community organizations can all paint ecosystems and modifiers on a web map, and then calculate, entirely on the client, the effects of their changes in terms of environmental performance indicators (EPIs) centered around carbon flows, water flows, biodiversity, and human population. Our hope is to engage everyone, from city officials to schoolchildren, in the search for ecologically informed urban sustainability, by encouraging them to think of all types of ecosystems in New York, natural and built, as part of a vital natural whole.

The map painting interface we developed for this visionary user experience required innovative solutions to a number of issues around data storage, transmission, and manipulation -- each user "vision" stores multiple values per 10m raster cell for geographies as large as Manhattan island. An open-source stack based on PostGIS, GeoDjango, and our own compressible raster data schema provided the basis for these solutions that we think can be extended to vision-making applications for other geographies -- but we're looking to the FOSS4G community for feedback on how to build the next generation!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>941</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>Spatial Cypher - at last a query language for Neo4j Spatial</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=942</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[craig]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=942</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At FOSS4G 2010 we announced Neo4j Spatial, a GIS based on a real graph database. This was super for serious Java developers, but not easy for the rest of us. In the last few years Neo4j has been revolutionized by the development of Cypher, an intuitive query language for graph data and analysis, dramatically broadening its appeal. Now we've added Spatial features to Cypher, opening the door to easy, intuitive geoprocessing on this high performance graph database.

We will introduce Cypher, recap Neo4j Spatial and show you how expressive these spatial queries can be. If you have a complex data model that you want to simplify, or complex spatial queries you would rather have easy, this is the place for you.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>What&#039;s new in QGIS 2.4</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=943</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pka]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=943</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Following the long awaited QGIS 2 release in September 2013, the project decided to switch to a regular release cycle with three versions per year. QGIS 2.2 was the first release in this cycle and already packed with many new features like 1:n relations, gradient fills, native DXF export and NTv2 datum transformations to name a few. QGIS 2.4, released in June, has one major extension in its core: multithreaded rendering. Originally developed as a Google Summer of Code project, it makes a big difference in the responsiveness of QGIS desktop.
This talk shows a selection of the latest features and gives an outlook what's in the works for QGIS 2.6. Some interesting plugins and other news from the community will keep you up to date with the high pace of this OSGeo project.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>An Easy Web Mapping Framework</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=944</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mtnclimb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=944</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Browser technologies such as HTML, JavaScript and CSS have matured to a point where they can be used to develop sophisticated applications. Spatial JavaScript libraries such as OpenLayers, JSTS and D3 supply great capability for implementing mapping and graphing applications. Complex geoprocessing functions such as geocoding, routing and surface analysis can now be accessed easily via REST API’s.
These technologies provide a powerful set of tools for building the next generation of client-side web mapping applications. But this tool set is complex, and requires significant effort in UI design to make it accessible to users. The BC Government Natural Resource Sector (NRS) deploys over a hundred web mapping applications. Implementing these applications using one-off designs would be prohibitively costly in development, support and training. This talk discusses the development of a Common Web Mapping framework based on OpenLayers 2, which uses the power of modern browser technology to provide a fast and easy way to build web mapping applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>State of QGIS Server</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=945</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pka]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=945</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[QGIS server continues to grow with an active community and expanding user base. Besides new styling features shared with QGIS desktop, new services have been added continuously. OGC WFS (Web Feature Service) and WFS-T were the first additions to WMS, recently followed by an OGC WCS (Web Coverage Service) implementation. The map service itself also got several additions besides the GetPrint request for delivering PDF outputs made with QGIS print composer. Performance and scalabilty has been steadily improved and brought to the same level as other established map servers. PDF outputs got recently support for dynamic texts and images (e.g. QR codes) and server-side GeoJSON rendering allowing redlining implementations.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Journey to ISO Compliant Metadata Implementation in North Carolina</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=946</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[doug_newcomb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=946</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The North Carolina ad-hoc Metadata Committee, a subcommittee of the NC GICC (http://www.ncgicc.com/), has been established to create a standard local government Metadata profile for North Carolina that would comply with the developing  ISO 19115-1 metadata standard and to provide guidance on software tools and best practices .  Topics will include the mission of the committee, the specifics of developing a Local Government ISO profile, how to implement the profile,  software applications  reviewed and the impact of the partnerships required to achieve success.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Data.gov/Geoplatform.gov CSW implementation through pycsw and CKAN integration</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=947</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gcpp.kalxas]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=947</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will discuss the implementation of the CSW endpoint using pycsw within the Data.gov infrastructure (architecture/enhancements/testing/deployment) and CKAN, which powers Data.gov.

CSW (Catalogue Service for the Web) is an OGC (Open Geospatial Consortium) specification that defines common interfaces to discover, browse, and query metadata about data, services, and other potential resources.

Data.gov provides access to its catalog via the CSW standard for both first-order and all metadata for harvested data, services and applications. Data may be referenced from federal, state, local, tribal, academic, commercial, or non-profit organizations.  The first-order CSW endpoint provides collection level filtering of all metadata records. The all metadata CSW endpoint provides all levels of metadata at varying levels of granularity.  

Any client supporting CSW (desktop, GIS, web application, client library, etc.) can integrate the Data.gov CSW endpoints.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Easy ETL with OGR</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=948</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pka]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=948</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The ogrtools Python library lets you run complex ogr2ogr operations defined in a configuration file supporting transformations of all OGR vector formats. It uses the OGR Virtual Format (VRT) internally for transformations like renaming tables or columns, calculating values and converting data types. Since version 1.11 of GDAL/OGR, multiple geometry columns per table are fully supported for major data formats.
As a pure Python library using OGR Python bindings, it has no additional dependencies and is therefore easy to integrate in other applications like QGIS.
https://github.com/sourcepole/ogrtools]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Facilitating GIS Solutions with the NASA Global Imagery Management System</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=949</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[christian.alarcon]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=949</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The NASA’s Global Imagery Browse Service (GIBS) is the Earth Observation System (EOS) imagery solution for delivering global, full-resolution satellite imagery in a highly responsive manner to the public.  Behind this high-resolution imagery-delivery system is a horizontally-scaled data management and workflow system called The Imagery Exchange (TIE).  TIE is a collection of RESTful services that was built with open source software and designed for scalability and portability. It is an extension of the HORIZON data management and workflow architecture, a system developed and extensively used at the NASA Physical Oceanography Distributed Active Archive Center (PO.DAAC). The GIBS’ TIE development team is working on integrating advanced spatial imagery metadata solution that offers lineage to observation artifacts by leveraging the NASA’s EOS Clearing House (ECHO) system.  The solution chaperones the discovery and delivery of GIS polygon metadata and the dynamic generation of the getCapabilities  catalog used by web mapping services. This talk focuses on the current TIE development activities, such as collecting and delivering GIS information on GIBS imagery products.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Global Mapping of Fractional Snow at NASA</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=950</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[boustani]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=950</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the FOSS4G 2014 I will be presenting utilization of GIS (Geographic Information System) capabilities such as Geo Spatial data management, analysis, computation and visualization for one of the earth science projects at Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Snow Data System. Snow Data System efforts have been focused on supporting the Colorado Basin River Forecast Center, working on products in the Western United States and Alaska for the National Climate Assessment, as well as research efforts in the Hindu Kush Himalaya Region of Asia through the generation and publication of our MODSCAG, MODDRFS and MODICE products.
All of these three products need to be mapped after the data get available from MODIS satellite.

Our team developed a program that retrieves MODIS data from LP.DAAC, temporarily store it in JPL, runs scientists code over data, ingest them to Database (in this case PostGIS database) and uses WMS (web map service) to map the result over Aerial basemap. All of these process need to be done automatically and take less than an hour to make it available on a map on website. For MODSCAG and MODDRFS the process need to be repeated everyday and for MODICE for each year.

On this project we got benefit from variety of different GIS and Geo Spatial Open Source libraries and tools for data management, visualization, storage and Geo Spatial processing. In my presentation I will demonstrate the process of generating online webmaps and talking about the Open Source libraries and tools we have used along with the lessons we learned.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Community Data Generation and Diffusion: An Integrated Approach Facilitated Through Open-Source Tools</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=951</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[cjseeger]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=951</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Several obstacles impact the ability of University Extension and Outreach leaders and specialists to make effective decisions using data: 1) Accessing up-to-date information is tedious and requires visits to numerous data sources. 2) The volume of data available makes it difficult to identify the appropriate information contained in it. 3) Users do not have access to or the technical ability to use complex geospatial and visualization tools. 4) Users don’t have the education to understand how to critically evaluate this information and turn it into actionable ideas. 

Funded by the state university, a decision support and visualization web-tool that would help reduce these obstacles was developed. The tool allows users’ to view and evaluate the state’s community, county and regional data and share this information with citizens and local leaders through their outreach activities. This proposal presents a case study showcasing how the project was developed, an overview and review of the open-source tools selected and examples of how the project provides opportunities for data collection, data sharing, report generation, and easy access to ever-changing data sets. The case study will also illustrate how the design team opened the system up to allow university experts the opportunity to become data custodians and provide novice users with information critical to properly interpret the data. The presentation will include an overview of tools that allow end users to mash their own data with existing data sets as well as customize the data visualization for color and layout and more impactful options such as margin-of-error or economic inflation.

The presented project will include discussion of several technologies including D3.js, Crosslet, Leaflet, geoJSON/TopoJSON and Drupal.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Client-side versus server-side geoprocessing: Benchmarking the performance of web browsers processing geospatial data using common GIS algorithms.</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=952</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[erin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=952</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Are web browsers ready to handle a larger portion of the processing load in our GIS applications? Web-based GIS and mapping applications are traditionally based on a client-server model, where most of the data processing work is placed on the server. This study examines what happens when that processing load is shifted to the client-side, using JavaScript to process geospatial data with GIS algorithms directly in the browser.

The performance, which in this study refers to number of milliseconds to complete a task, of common GIS algorithms using the JavaScript library JSTS Topology Suite were benchmarked in popular web browsers including Chrome, Firefox, Internet Explorer, Opera, and Safari. The GIS algorithms buffer, union, and Voronoi triangulation were tested with a suite of points, lines, and polygons ranging in size from 10 up to 100,000 vertices. The testing platforms included Windows, Mac, and Linux desktops and laptops.

The same geoprocessing tests were conducted on a cloud-based Linux server using the Java library JTS Topology Suite as a performance comparison of server-side processing applications. The various testing configurations were then analyzed to see how browsers stack up to the performance of traditional client-server applications.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GRASS GIS 7: your reliable geospatial number cruncher</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=953</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[markus.neteler]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=953</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[GRASS GIS (Geographic Resources Analysis Support System) looks back to the longest development history in the FOSS4G community. Having been available for 30 years, a lot of innovation has been put into the new GRASS GIS 7 release. After six years of development it offers a lot of new functionality, e.g. enhanced vector network analysis, voxel processing, a completely new engine for massive time series management, an animation tool for raster and vector map time series, a new graphic image classification tool, a "map swiper" for interactive maps comparison, and major improvements for massive data analysis (see also http://grass.osgeo.org/grass7/). The development was driven by the rapidly increasing demand for robust and modern free analysis tools, especially in terms of massive spatial data processing and processing on high-performance computing systems. With respect to GRASS GIS 6.4 more than 10,000 source code changes have since been made.
GRASS GIS 7 provides a new powerful Python interface that allows users to easily create new applications that are powerful and efficient. The topological vector library has been improved in terms of accuracy, processing speed, and support for large files. Furthermore, projections of planets other than Earth are now supported as well. Many modules have been significantly optimized in terms of speed even by orders of magnitude. The presentation will showcase the new features along with real-world examples and the integration with QGIS, gvSIG CE, R statistics, and the ZOO WPS engine.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Assessing the distribution of disease vectors and fruit crop pests from satellite in GRASS GIS 7</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=954</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[markus.neteler]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=954</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the past decades, disease vectors like the Asian tiger mosquito (Aedes albopictus) transmitting Dengue Fever and other infections and the Spotted Wing Drosophila (Drosophila suzukii), an economically important fruit crop pest, have continued to globally expand. In Europe, the already invaded areas comprise the Mediterranean basin while the spread to the north of the Alps is ongoing. Likewise many regions in the world face an increasing risk for new or re-emerging vector-borne diseases transmitted by mosquitoes. Given this spread, there is an urgent need to gain better understanding of spatio-temporal patterns in disease transmission and agro-pest diffusion. The  life cycles of mosquitoes and fruit flies depend on climatic and environmental conditions which can be observed using satellite sensors. We identified the potential distribution areas linked to the current climatic suitability through the evaluation of remotely sensed land surface temperature (LST) data for Northern Italy and Switzerland. For this we processed with GRASS GIS 7 more than a decade of daily MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) satellite sensor data at continental scale (250 m resolution, four maps per day) as an alternative to meteorological data. Since LST data often contain gaps due to cloud cover, these gaps were filled by reconstructing any missing LST values before environmental indicators have been derived from these data. From the gap-filled LST data (in the multi terabyte range) we derived threshold maps like January mean temperatures as a threshold to estimate the survival chances of overwintering diapausing eggs, whereas the annual mean temperature can be used as a threshold to estimate population stability. We derived growing degree days (GDD) as well by temporal aggregation. The approach can be applied to continents other than Europe, too. The resulting potential distribution maps can be leveraged to assess the spread of disease vectors and agro-pests in order to assist decision makers and public health authorities to develop surveillance plans and vector control.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Health]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[12.9.2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_day</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>schedule_session</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Evolving web mapping tools with FOSS4G</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=955</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pfrontiera]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=955</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The San Francisco Estuary Institute (www.sfei.org) has been creating FOSS4G web tools to support ecosystem science and watershed management for over ten years.  These tools need to meet the rigor of our staff scientists who want the results of their work communicated correctly and our GIS analysts who want the functionality and robustness of proprietary (ESRI) software. On the other hand our tools need to meet the needs of diverse stakeholders including land use planners, managers, decision-makers and the general public who want information communicated in a useful as well as easy to use way.  This talk presents three of the tools we have re-created –  dramatically transformed in version 2.0 to take advantage of technological advances, better respond to stakeholder needs, and address changing institutional objectives, including
1.	EcoAtlas.org an OpenLayers+Mapserver+Postgres site reengineered with a dynamic landscape analysis reporting tool that leverages PostGIS vector and raster processing. 
2.	Cramwetlands.org:  a site that uses drupal and cartaroto to support a secure full-CRUD WFS-T feature editor based on OpenLayers, Geoserver, and Postgis.
3.	CD3AQT:  a new version of our contaminant data explorer (http://www.sfei.org/tools/wqt) extended with R/Rapache for dynamically generating statistical plots and surface models.

The big issues that these revisions pose for us as an institution and which will be discussed are: 
•	Increased sophistication in our tools makes them more expensive to build and maintain. What is the strategic technical game plan to leverage our initial investments to maintain and extend these tools?
•	Our scientists traditionally communicate the results of their work via print reports or PDFs. What is the relationship between these traditional work products and our web tools?
•	In an organization that monitors the environment and collects unique data (eg over 10 years of monitoring data on the San Francisco Bay) what is the best way to share those data / provide external access?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Open Source Work-flow for Surface Interpolation with Curvilinear Anisotropy</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=956</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mmtobias]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=956</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Traditional approaches to interpolating a surface from point samples often assume that if anisotropy is present in the data, it is along a straight line.  However, this assumption breaks down for many data-sets, such as river bathymetry, elevations near coastlines, or levels of pollutants along roads.  I will present a work-flow using open source tools to make use of the curvilinear anisotropy present in many data-sets by transforming the curved data-set into a straight line (QGIS and PostGIS), applying an interpolation to the transformed data (SAGA, GRASS, or other program with interpolation tools), and finally re-bending the interpolated surface back to the data's original shape (PostGIS).]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Building Your Community IRL: Why, How, and How to Stay Sane</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=957</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kathleen.danielson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=957</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Organizing and supporting a technical community of any flavor is hard work-- anyone who says otherwise has never tried it! You aren't alone though; many people have been trying this for years and you can learn from our mistakes.

This talk will share the Whys and Hows of building a healthy local technical community. We'll talk about different models for local geo communities, from local OpenStreetMap user groups to more general geo tech meetups and beyond. We'll also discuss techniques to make sure that you as an organizer have the support that you need to be successful.

We will cover:

- Reasons for building in-person communities
- Finding your community and spreading the word
- Listening to your group's needs and providing good programming
- Avoiding Burnout, and other essentials of Community Manager Self-Care
- Ideas for the future of our communities]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Groundwater Levels and the New California Water Atlas</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=958</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[erictheise]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=958</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When the California Water Atlas was published in 1979, Charles
Wollenberg, writing in the California Historical Quarterly, called it "a
very big and beautiful book... well-written, spectacularly illustrated,
and filled with useful information for expert and layman alike... an
indispensable sourcebook for decades to come." And while it's still
regarded as a high water mark for its intelligent and expository
writing, its maps and its visualizations, enough decades have passed for
the underlying data to show its tarnish.

Inspired by the original, The New California Water Atlas endeavors to
make a complex system understandable, taking a comprehensive perspective
on the governance and use of water throughout California. The NCWA
explores innovative ways to show water resources both geographically and
through interactive data visualizations. Technology and the Internet
allow a once static tool, the printed atlas, to become a living,
breathing entity.

This talk will cover the reimplementation and expansion of one of the
NCWA's focus areas, historic groundwater levels across the state. Topics
will include:

* acquiring datasets from the California Department of Water Resources
* importing and validating data
* designing and implementing a publicly-consumable RESTful API
* the NCWA's own API consumption for generating tables, maps, and other visualizations

The project is implemented using standard FOSS4G packages, including
GeoDjango, PostgreSQL &amp; PostGIS, Leaflet, and D3.

Time permitting, other notable examples of recent, timely features and
online cartography will be highlighted.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>WPS Benchmarking Session</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=959</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gerald.fenoy]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=959</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the interrest for OGC Web Processing Service growing, we need to know details about the Open Source Solutions available. Various projects implementing WPS designed individuals from their community to participate in this talk to introduce their project and summarize their key features, they are the following:  52°North WPS, Constellation SDI, GeoServer, PyWPS, ZOO-Project. For being able to provide good quality results, the tests should be run locally, so a server dedicated to this WPS Benchmarking Session, hosting OSGeoLive environments, is accessible to each team for running test procedures defined through discussions. The results of the given test procedures will be presented during this session and will compare implementations from different aspects: capabilities, compliancy, ressources usage and performance.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Using the Department of Energy&#039;s APIs to create dynamic maps and graphics</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=960</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daniel.wood]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=960</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[## APIs + Energy

In the last few years, more and more publicly funded data has become machine readable and therefore possible to use in automated systems. The President's Executive Order on Making Open and Machine Readable the New Default for Government Information brought new data sets into the open that had previously been stuck behind extensive lines of red tape and bureaucracy.

At the Department of Energy, we have several outstanding APIs that include information on utility rates (reverse geocoded by lat, long input), petroleum prices, electricity consumption by state and region, location of alternative fuel stations, solar radiation by lat/long, and wind turbine data. These APIs are rapidly improving their documentation and support and many more are being brought online regularly. The use cases for these data on mobile applications and websites are manifold, and the Department of Energy has regularly hosted Apps for Energy Challenges, encouraging innovation and use of these APIs in the wild.

These APIs are a key tool in our mapping stack - they provide the most up-to-date data without manual updates, data collection or scrubbing. All this time saved allows us to produce more interactive visualizations. These visualizations are powered by Leaflet, Mapbox, and D3. We can often do some of these API calls in the client using javascript, plus geoJSON and topoJSON, so maps immediately reflect updating APIs feeds. Other times, we can use python on the server side to update the data at regular interveals.

### Outline

After bringing the audience up to speed on the above information, my talk will consist of 
 - Giving practical examples on the powers of using DOE's APIs. 
 - Show a survey of the Department's APIs and how we're leveraging them in the server and the browser.
 - Discuss best practices and common mistakes in using DOE APIs in cartographic products. 
 - Walk through how to ship these applications in order to avoid errors and breaks in service.
 - How best to integrate these APIs into Leaflet/Mapbox and D3 maps.

I imagine this talk being most useful to newer users to FOSS4G, particularly newer programmers and folks transitioning away from traditional GIS to a more programatic approach. It will stress the importance of APIs, Python, and Javascript in accomplishing excellent web cartography. Talks like these really helped me get my start when I was a n00b.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>TileMill and the Tower of Prince Henry, Reversed</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=961</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[erictheise]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=961</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Programs that generate map tiles default to generating tiles for a
bounding box whose dimensions are fixed up and down the zoom stack. But
the overarchingly common use case calls this default behavior into
question. If the ultimate goal of a map is to lock down the display of a
feature at a high zoom level, then any tile outside of the inverted
pyramid whose truncated top bounds the feature at the desired zoom level
is extraneous, unnecessary.

Inspired by a game of marbles that uses a similar shape in its playing,
I call this truncated, inverted pyramid the "Tower of Prince Henry,
Reversed"[1], and abbreviate it TOPHR.

This presentation describes modifications to TileMill, the same strategy
implemented directly through Mapnik XML, the use of the flexible mbtile
format to store the generated tiles, and presents several measures of
the resulting savings (tile generation time, number of tiles, disk
space). I'll also describe a plug in for Leaflet and an approach for
OpenLayers that ensures that map users cannot stray outside the bounds
of TOPHR.

1. It's also reminiscent of the name of a real album by The Fall or an unreal tarot card.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Spatial Temporal Network Web Visualization Techniques</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=962</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[naefish]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=962</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Maps are traditional means of presentation and tools for analysis of spatial information. The power of maps can be also put into service in analysis of spatio-temporal data, i.e. data about phenomena that change with time. Exploration of such data requires highly interactive and dynamic maps. Using geospatial open source software, various techniques for visualizing spatial temporal network change data and combinations of spatial temporal network, point and area data are evaluated.  Linear referencing represents locations along routes, linear features with an established measurement system, using relative positions. It allows locating events along routes without segmenting it, and has been applied to manage linear features in transportation, utilities, along trail networks and stream networks. Linear referencing for events occurring along a network through time are visualized using both animations and interactive time line visualizations.  Sliders are used to give the user manual control to step through the data, allowing them to explore the data presented in each time step.  Categorized point events (i.e. traffic accident types, flood locations, etc.) appear at muItiple locations along the network.  Color and size of symbols are used to denote these dynamic point event attribute changes and location changes.  In addition, line segments are mapped using size and color to identify the changes occurring over time.  Some of the combinations of changes evaluated include: attribute change (i.e. traffic accident type), spatial attribute change (i.e. flood boundaries), moving objects (i.e. traffic accidents), rate of change (i.e. fish survival by stream segment) and spatio-temporal aggregation (i.e. multiple fish releases by watershed). Some linear visualization techniques evaluated include: run maps and map and line chart visualization techniques similar to the famous Napoleon's retreat Minard visualization.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Modeling continental-scale 1-km real-sky solar radiation using r.sun algorithm (GRASS)</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=963</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[giuseppe.amatulli]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=963</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Incoming solar radiation has a primary influence on the structure and distribution of biodiversity, yet has not been estimated globally at high resolution. Variation in radiation depends on a number of factors, including position of the earth in relation to the sun, latitude, topography, and meteorological fluctuations (e.g. cloudiness, atmospheric turbidity, etc.) that may vary daily. Common methods for estimating incoming solar radiation typically do not account for this important spatially-explicit seasonal variability in atmospheric factors and instead estimate solar radiation under “clear-sky” conditions. 
The r.sun function, within the open source Geographical Resources Analysis Support System (GRASS), can be used to estimate clear-sky and real-sky daily solar energy, so called global radiation. We estimate and validate monthly mean global solar radiation at 1km spatial resolution in the conterminous United States. We use Global Multi-resolution Terrain Elevation Data 2010, latitude and sun position to compute total daily global solar radiation using two methods: 1) clear-sky and 2) real-sky incorporating MODIS-derived atmospheric observations. The clear-sky method calculates the total amount of solar radiation while ignoring the influence of the atmosphere. On the other hand, the real-sky MODIS-derived method uses the daily MODIS Terra/Aqua products, such as aerosol optical thickness, albedo, and cloudiness to atmospherically correct the clear-sky conditions. Daily aerosol optical thickness was obtained by analyzing temporal mean Collection 6 MODIS Aqua Level-2 aerosol (MYD04_3K) which is a daily dataset along the period 2002-2014, with a pixel resolution of 3 km. Daily albedo was obtained by temporal interpolation of Filled Land Surface Albedo Product (white-sky 0.3-5.0µm wavelengths) which is a 16-day composite with a pixel resolution of 2 km. Daily cloud frequency was obtained by temporal interpolation of mean monthly cloud frequency derived from 2000-2013 MODIS PGE11 cloud flags. The computed daily global solar radiation were then aggregated to mean monthly global radiation.
The generated monthly mean global solar radiation estimation was validated by a comparison of observation data obtained by the 1991–2010 National Solar Radiation Database maintained by the Renewable Resource Data Center. Incorporating the atmospheric effects significantly improves the prediction of real-sky global solar radiation, reducing the root-mean square error between the modelled monthly mean global radiation and the observations. Moreover, the validation procedure allows adjusting the estimated values for systematic bias to improve predictions.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>963</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>Real-time Scenario Planning with OpenLayers</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=964</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[sfletche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=964</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Area-based planning processes are rapidly moving from paper and desktop GIS based processes to online applications offering real-time analysis and feedback. Users want an interactive and informative experience allowing them to generate reports and analysis without needing to understand the subtleties of GIS or spatial analysis.  They expect a compelling user experience that works on a variety of platforms – ranging from old or outdated browsers to tablets and smart phones.

Building from years of experience (and standing on many shoulders), this talk demonstrates some of the strategies and techniques achieved for the Marine Planner platform, an online open-source map viewer and decision support tool.  These strategies include UTFGrids, tile caching, pre-processing, and standard and forked OpenLayer libraries, among others.  The result is large-scale scenario planning tools with a responsive and compelling user-experience that anyone who has used online maps can figure out.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoNetwork opensource 3.0</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=965</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jeroen.Ticheler]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=965</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The presentation will provide an insight of the new functionality available in the latest release of the software. Publishing and managing spatial metadata using GeoNetwork opensource has become main stream in many Spatial Data Infrastructures. 
GeoNetwork opensource 3.0 comes with a new, clean user interface based on AngularJS, Bootstrap and D3. Other topics presented are related to performance, scalability, usability, workflow, metadata profile plugins and catalogue services compliance. 
Examples of implementations of the software will also be given, highlighting several national European SDI portals as well as work for Environment Canada and the collaboration with the OpenGeoPortal project.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoTools, GeoServer, GeoGit:  A Case Study of Use in Utility Field Work</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=966</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[phansen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=966</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After creating a custom application featuring ArcSDE and the ESRI Mobile SDK for use by the field crew from a local Mosquito and Vector Abatement District, we sought an alternative to the high overhead from the proprietary software.  By utilizing GeoTools, GeoServer, and GeoGit, we were able to develop a full-fledged application maintaining the same functionality and usability of the original application, without the high cost of entry.

The GeoTools application, "Mosquito," and GeoServer, were placed on each of the field laptops of the twenty-member crew, serving both the application and cached base layers to allow for offline data connection.  A USB Bluetooth GPS dongle was used to allow workers to locate themselves within the application.  GeoGit was utilized to allow the disparate field workers to merge and synchronize data to the master database at the end of their shift.]]></content:encoded>
