	<item>
				<title>GeoCat Live and GeoCat Bridge</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=967</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jeroen.Ticheler]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=967</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[GeoCat Bridge helps to bridge the gap between proprietary and open source solutions. The goal of this product is to provide a solution that makes it extremely easy for users to publish their data on a GeoNetwork, GeoServer and/or MapServer based server solution. The tool converts the ArcMap symbology to symbology optimized for GeoServer and MapServer. Data can be loaded to the server on the file system or straight into PostGIS. It manages metadata at the source and publishes it as clean ISO19139 metadata. This extension creates a bridge where both proprietary, open source solution providers and open standards supporters are winners.

GeoCat Live offers a solid, scalable Spatial Data Infrastructure to store, describe and publish your data. You don’t have to worry about new software releases, about keeping your servers working, about scaling or about desktop integration. You can just focus on the (geospatial) data you want to publish. Your data will be accessible as a service. You can build the applications you want to offer to your users on top of these services.

GeoCat supports governments and businesses with geospatial catalog applications based on GeoNetwork opensource. GeoCat Bridge and GeoCat Live are build with this experience in mind. The result is a geospatial infrastructure that is easier to maintain and is very cost effective for our clients.]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In addition to hosting the popular OSM-base Toner, Watercolor, and Terrain tile sets, Stamen incorporates custom cartography into much of our client work. 				<title>Advanced CartoCSS Tricks</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=969</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>

Tips and tricks covered include, but will not be limited to: pixelation, use of dingbat fonts for texture and markers, post-facto label adjustment, alternate uses for text symbolization, where to find and use entropy, blending, and geometry manipulation.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapRoom: a high performance Desktop Mapping and Data Manipulation Program.</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=970</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rob.mcmullen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=970</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our group provides scientific support to the responders for oil and chemical spills in US coastal waters. In order to perform our work, we have the need to manipulate a wide variety of geospatial data, ranging from large unstructured grids for hydrodynamic models to the results of particle tracking models used for oil spills and other analysis. For presentation of results to the response community, we need to overlay results on large raster or vector nautical charts, shapefiles, netcdf and HDF5 scientific data sets, as well as a large number of special purpose data formats. In addition, we have a need to easily plug-in custom data processing.

This work overlaps the worlds of traditional GIS and scientific computing. In our analysis of available tools, no existing solution met our use cases. Tools designed for scientific data visualization often do not handle geo-spatial data (and particularly projections) well, and desktop GIS systems do not map well to the unconventional data models we need to work with, including 3D and 4D data (x,y,z and time), and annotation that is closely linked with data. In addition, both categories of tools are primarily focused on visualization and analysis of existing data sets, rather than creating data from scratch.

Thus to meet our mission, a custom open source solution has been developed. It is a desktop application designed to be multi-platform and easy to extend. The application is written in Python to provide rapid development and easy extension, and makes heavy use of the numpy package for computational performance. Rendering is handled with OpenGL to provide highly optimized performance, particularly for scaling raster images. The result is an easy to use, high performing, and easy to extend framework for data manipulation and visualization. The presentation will highlight the core features of the application, its structure, and provide a quick overview of how one might extend the application by adding a new custom layer type.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>“Sliding” datasets together to improve Open Street Map imports</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=971</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[paulmach]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=971</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Importing new/updated geometry into the Open Street Map database is tricky business. Features represented in both datasets need to be detected and merged. Slide is a tool to help maximize the efficiency of map editors during this process.

Slide works by iteratively refining roads, trails and other complex geometries to match another dataset where the features are correctly mapped. This is done in a single click where one geometry is “slided” to the other. The existing method requires resampling the OSM data to match, a process that could take hundreds of clicks. 

The form of the new dataset is flexible. It could be an updated representation of roads such as the new TIGER database, a handful of GPS track collected by humanitarian workers, or a large collection of GPS data points like the 250+ billion made available by Strava, a fitness tracking website.

At its core, Slide is designed to leverage what we already know, collected in various datasets, to speed map tracing for OSM. Map editors should not be retracing another dataset but focusing on higher level challenges.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>971</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>Making Open Data informative for Citizens and easy for Government</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=972</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ajturner]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=972</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[No one cares so much about a neighborhood as the people who live there. Government exists to provide necessary services and support for its citizens and encourage the growth of business. But how can citizens, developers and businesses help themselves to work better with government?

Open Data has many promises to improve civil society, encourage business growth, and make government more efficient. The reality has been many open data efforts are difficult to maintain, have limited utility, and difficult to measure impact. 

Web technology has evolved, and people are more comfortable engaging with dynamic, collaborative, and increasingly mobile access to information. Open Data should be the fuel to enable developers to quickly build great open-source applications, citizens to easily understand their neighborhoods, and businesses to leverage public resources for better operations. 

Additionally open data is vital to understanding a changing climate and local landscape. Through pre-positioning of open data communities can prepare to help themselves such as access to infrastructure data like shelters and the tools to update and digitally support first responders in a disaster.

This talk will share the experiences and insights in designing, developing, and growing an open data platform that spans the world. By providing open access through the web, using lightweight data standards, and accurate but easy to use tools - users can find open data to discover delightful and useful information to improve their lives and cities. 

Built on an architecture of loosely coupled open-source technology components such as Koop, ElasticSearch, and GeoServices, open data is easy to deploy and maintain without requiring difficult and unsustainable process changes for governments. Open-source Javascript libraries such as Recline.js and Leaflet.js offer modern interactive interfaces that are familiar to users making them comfortable to search and explore open data. 

Through all of this work, it is clear that we are just at the beginning of realizing the potential for open data. Within the year we will see orders of magnitude availability of data, information, and tools that will mean a wealth of resources for engaging citizens, developers and businesses together with government.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>972</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-15 18:17:55</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[open data,government,community,collaboration]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[end-user]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key>notes_to_organizers</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[may be able to get a government representative to speak on their experiences and realities within government on the efforts and benefits of open data]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Creating Map Style &amp; Visibility Rules from Statistics</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=973</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[reholl]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=973</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Map style, label, and visibility rules, especially those aimed at differentiating "important" classes of features from "minor" ones, can be derived from statistical functions performed on feature attributes.  If the source data classification scheme is not already strong in prioritizing features how we want to view them, then style patterns may emerge from calculations over an assortment of counts, sums, averages, and other measurements.  

We will begin with a quick examination of popular open source web and desktop mapping engines -- do their configuration capabilities include formal constructs for deriving rules from statistics?  Or must the developer arrive at "this looks right" through trial and error?  

We'll extend the discussion to specific data distribution patterns that can be exploited for styling. We're accustomed to setting line styles, symbol and font sizes, colors, and visibility at different scales.  The bell curve resulting from a query may point us to where we make the scale breaks, or toward how much color or size contrast to employ in order to make the best presentation from the particular data we are displaying.  Perhaps we can arrange our queries, thereby grouping our features a certain way, to aim for an "ideal" curve that is already known to produce pleasing results.

A simple set of query tools for streamlining style assists from statistics will be used to create a few examples from troublesome data.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>973</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-15 18:19:58</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[statistics, distribution curve, mapping, styles, configuration, visibility, classification, query tools]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Finding the Where in Big Fuzzy Data</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=974</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ajturner]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=974</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We've gone to plaid. 

It is now easier to store any and all information that we can because it _might_ be useful later. Like a data hoarder, we would rather keep everything than throw any of it away. As a result, we now are knee-deep in bits that we are not quite sure are useful or meaningful. 

Fortunately, there is now a mature, and growing, family of open-source tools that make it straight-forward to organize, process and query all this data to find useful information. Hadoop has been synonymous with, and arguably responsible for, the rise of 'The Big Data'. But it's not your grandfather's mapreduce framework anymore (ok, in internet time). There are a number of open-source frameworks, tools, and techniques that are emerging that each provide a different speciality when managing and process fast, big, voracious data streams.

As a Geo-community we understand the potential for location to be the common context through which we can combine disparate information. In large amounts of data with wide variety, location enables us to discover correlations that can be amazing insights that otherwise were lost when looking through our pre-defined and overly structured databases. And by using modern big data tools, we can now rapidly process queries which means we can experiment with more ideas in less time.

This talk will share open-source projects that geo-enable these big data frameworks as well as use case examples of how they have been used to solve unique and interesting problems that would have taken forever to run or may not have even been possible.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Supporting Open Data with Open Source</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=975</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[micah.wengren]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=975</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Within the US Federal Government, there is a trend towards embracing the benefits of open data to increase transparency and maximize potential innovation and resulting economic benefit from taxpayer investment.  Recently, an Executive Order was signed specifically requiring federal agencies to provide a public inventory of their non-restricted data and to use standard web-friendly formats and services for public data access.  

For geospatial data, popular free and open source software packages are ideal options to implement an open data infrastructure.  NOAA, an agency whose mission has long embraced and indeed centered on open data, has recently deployed or tested several FOSS products to meet the open data executive order.  Among these are GeoServer, GeoNode, and CKAN, or Comprehensive Knowledge Archive Network, a data management and publishing system.

This talk will focus on how these three FOSS products can be deployed together to provide an open data architecture exclusively built on open source.  Data sets hosted in GeoServer can be cataloged and visualized in GeoNode, and fed to CKAN for search and discovery as well as translation to open data policy-compliant JSON format.  Upcoming enhancements to GeoNode, the middle tier of the stack, will allow integration with data hosting backends other than GeoServer, such as Esri's ArcGIS REST services or external WMS services.  

We'll highlight NOAA's existing implementation of the above, including the recently-deployed public data catalog, https://data.noaa.gov/, and GeoServer data hosting platform, as well as potential build out of the full stack including the GeoNode integration layer.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A FOSS4G-Based Geo Connection System for Education and Research</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=976</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[dstrohschein]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=976</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This proposed presentation is intended for academicians who are comfortable using open source FOSS4G and are considering installing an enterprise Linux system using FOSS4G. The presentation will examine the selection, installation, and the current and planned use of a CentOS – based system running FOSS4G to support the Geography Department at Salem State University in Salem, MA. 
Universities, as is the case with most businesses, seek to provide necessary computing resources in a cost-effective manner. The Department realizes the benefit of combining inexpensive hardware, and free and open source software (FOSS) to support its work as an educator of students, a research entity, and a partner in collaborative work with state and local organizations. As a result, the system, known as the Geo Connection System or GCS, serves as a resource for both graduate and undergraduate students within the department. Additionally, the system enhances student, department, and University research; and fosters further collaborative work between SSU and the community. 
	At present, the GCS is being used to better understand and enhance distribution systems associated with local agriculture producers and consumers. Part of this work is the development, in cooperation with the SSU Center for Economic Development and Sustainability (CEDS), of a web-based system to process and serve geospatial information in an effort to improve communication between food producers and consumers, i.e. restaurants, farmers markets, and Community Supported Agriculture (CSA). Planned uses for the GCS include the following:
•	Continued investigation of the general principles and approaches for designing food distribution systems to enhance local food networks
•	Continued access to a web-based system for geospatial computations and data management
•	Continued service as a resource for the community to access information in support of the broader goals of the CEDS research center
•	To act as an map server 
•	To act as the server supporting deployment of geo-aware mobile phone applications implemented by the department to enhance the learning process on field trips and other field work 
•	To collect, process, store, and serve data from environmental sensors to support education in weather, climate, and the environment]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Mobile Situated Learning Module using Open Source Geoweb Technology</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=977</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[northlandiguana]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=977</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Mobile device technology is being introduced into educational settings and is likely to become widespread as an instructional medium in the coming years. As of 2013, nearly three-fourths of American college students own a smartphone, while four in ten own a tablet, and a majority of students believe that mobile devices can make their education more effective. There is tremendous opportunity to harness these devices for situated learning, or lessons that take place in a real-world context, through the use of mobile-ready geoweb technologies. Adaptive web maps can be developed to guide students to important places—either virtually or physically—and facilitate landmark interpretation. This presentation will demonstrate a situated learning module developed using open source geoweb technologies for an International Studies course at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The purpose of the module is to “make the familiar strange” to students in the Madison landscape, guiding them to historic landmarks and pairing those places with maps, images, and narration to explore the course of economic development in the U.S. The web application makes use of the principles of responsive web design to adapt to mobile or desktop devices, altering the map interface and modes of content delivery to fit the user’s context. The mobile and desktop versions will each be evaluated to determine what adaptations effectively increased usability and whether situated viewing of the map on a mobile device influenced learning outcomes. A review of the application development and evaluation processes and results will be accompanied by a summary of lessons learned about how mobile mapping applications can adapt to their users and surroundings.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Anchoring and PostGIS cure Post-Polygon Stress Disorder</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=978</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[yao.cui]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=978</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Polygons are great to have in digital maps, much like a canvas that we can render with beautiful colours. It is common that polygon boundaries are shared by linear features (e.g., municipalities divided by a river or a road). If polygons are used as part of the base to edit, update, and integrate digital maps, we have to reconcile the geometric differences among the shared boundaries and fix topological problems in edge matching. For many years we felt blessed that commercial software tools are available to reconcile shared boundaries, and to detect and fix topological problems. However, if wrestling with polygons leaves you feeling buried in slivers, discontinuities, gaps, and overlaps, you’ve got Post-Polygon Stress Disorder (PPSD). 

PostgreSQL/PostGIS presented British Columbia Geological Survey an opportunity to identify the causes of PPSD. As a result, we have developed a geologic framework data model and implemented an anchoring mechanism in PostGIS to simplify the process of editing, updating, and integrating digital geological maps. We have dispensed with polygons and eliminated the problems from shared boundaries and edge matching.

Healing to PPSD is available in this poster:
http://www.empr.gov.bc.ca/Mining/Geoscience/PublicationsCatalogue/GeoFiles/Pages/2014-9.aspx.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>978</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-04-15 19:04:49</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>session</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>keywords</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[PostGIS, data integration, edge matching, shared boundaries, digital geology]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>target_audience</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[end-user, manager, developers]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Big (enough) data and strategies for distributed geoprocessing</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=979</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rkraft4]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=979</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Big data gets a lot of press these days, but even if you're not geocoding the Twitter firehose, "big enough" data can be a pain - whether you're crashing your database server or simply running out of RAM. Distributed geoprocessing can be even more painful, but for the right job it's a revelation!

This session will explore strategies you can use to unlock the power of distributed geoprocessing for the "big enough" datasets that make your life difficult. Granted, geospatial data doesn't always fit cleanly into Hadoop's MapReduce framework. But  with a bit of creativity - think in-memory joins, hyper-optimized data schemas, and offloading work to API services or PostGIS - you too can get Hadoop MapReduce working on your geospatial data!

Real-world examples will be taken from work on GlobalForestWatch.org, a new platform for exploring and analyzing global data on deforestation. I'll be demoing key concepts using Cascalog, a Clojure wrapper for the Cascading Java library that makes Hadoop and Map/Reduce a lot more palatable. If you prefer Python or Scala, there are wrappers for you too.

Hadoop is no silver bullet, but for the right geoprocessing job it's a powerful tool.]]></content:encoded>

		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=980</link>

Focus will then shift to the main features and enhancements coming in MapServer 7.0 including dynamic heatmaps, WFS 2.0 support, UTFGrid generation and more. Finally we'll finish with a discussion of contribution opportunities for interested developers and users.

This a great opportunity to chat with the members of the MapServer project team!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Geolode: the motherlode of geospatial data sources</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=981</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kgj2]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=981</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You can't make a map without data.  A wealth of free and publicly-accessible geospatial data exists on thousands of websites scattered around the world, just waiting to be found and used.  But finding the right data for a specific map or analysis requires the knowledge of what geodata websites are out there, and what types of data they each contain.  Searching the web can turn up webpages that contain sprawling lists of geodata websites, but such lists are not easily browseable, and are often out of date.

Geolode.org is a newly-launched lightweight catalog of geodata websites around the world, searchable and browseable by location, topic, and other tags, so that searchers can quickly focus on the most relevant websites for their geodata needs.  An API also provides open access to the catalog's records in JSON format.

Geolode's inventory is the collaborative product of a group of librarians and other researchers with many years of experience searching for a wide range of data.  We'll talk about how Geolode works, as well as strategies for keeping Geolode up to date, such as harvesting links from all those sprawling lists, and monitoring Twitter for reports of new geodata resources.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Development of a Comprehensive US Transit Accessibility Database</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=982</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[owenx148]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=982</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation describes the development of the Accessibility Observatory’s national public transit job accessibility evaluation framework, focusing on lessons learned, data source evaluation and selection, and examples of how accessibility evaluation can be applied to support transportation planning and performance measurement. 

The Accessibility Observatory at the University of Minnesota is dedicated to supporting the fields of transportation planning and analysis by developing and applying accessibility-based evaluation metrics in a consistent manner across the United States. A key component of the Observatory’s work has been the development of an integrated software framework for a nationwide evaluation of the accessibility to jobs provided by public transit systems. Application on a national scale involves assembling and processing a comprehensive national database of public transit network topology and travel times.

In order to satisfy the national scope of this accessibility evaluation, data sources were sought primarily for their ability to be collected and applied consistently across the entire U.S. This naturally led to data products of the U.S. Census Bureau, including TIGER geospatial datasets and block-level worker and job estimates from the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program.

Unlike Census data, public transit schedules are not available centrally but must, with a few exceptions, be collected individually from transit agencies. The now-widespread GTFS data format brings benefits and challenges. Within the context of a single schedule dataset, the GTFS format allows the use of a variety of powerful tools for schedule analysis and travel time calculation. However, the GTFS format provides no mechanisms for canonically identifying operating agencies, specifying schedule validity in the case of temporal overlap, or identifying transit service that is duplicated under different names in multiple schedule files. We address some of these challenges and provide a summary of outstanding issues.

The core of the travel time and accessibility calculation engine is based on OpenTripPlanner, an open source transit routing software. OpenTripPlanner’s Analyst extension provides an interface for calculating shortest path trees, which visit all possible destinations from a single origin. The Observatory’s software development effort focused on feeding transit network, geography, and opportunity data into a scalable cluster of parallel accessibility calculation nodes implemented using cloud computing services.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>High performance upstream query by Graph and recursive Common Table Expressions</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=983</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[yao.cui]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=983</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A graph theory based data-store of triples was created using PostGIS to represent the stream network in the province of British Columbia (BC). PostgreSQL recursive Common Table Expressions (rCTEs) were used to traverse the graph and return upstream query results at any given locations on the streams. 

The graph data-store consists of 6.5 million triples that describe the relationships between drainage edges. The drainage edges are topographically represented at a scale of 1:20,000 and can also be used to retrieve watersheds delineated from mass points and breaklines in the digital elevation model (DEM). PostgreSQL/PostGIS is used to store the graph triples, streams and watersheds. 

The rCTEs based query takes only two minutes to retrieve the upstream edges for over 52,000 stream sediment sample sites, part of the Regional Geochemical Survey in BC. Using CascadedUnion in PostGIS, it takes another half an hour to resolve the 2 million watershed polygons and to produce the catchment basin for each of the sample sites.

This high performance upstream query has been packaged as a complete solution with interfaces to Web Services and Google Earth. Retrieved streams and catchment basins can be displayed in GIS or on Google Earth.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Intro to DDF – Distributed Geospatial Search &amp; Retrieval at its Finest</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=984</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeff.vettraino]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=984</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Distributed Data Framework (DDF) is a relatively new open source project centered on search and discovery of local and remote data.  DDF exposes data to clients through standardized interfaces such as OpenSearch with geospatial extensions and CSW.  DDF’s flexible transformation engine allows for the return of results in a variety of formats including XML, KML, and GeoJSON.  The distributed search capability of DDF allows federated searches to remote data sources with out of the box support for federating to Open Search sources, CSW sources, and WFS Sources.  Plugins can also be dynamically added to DDF to pull data from other data sources.  Additionally, DDF has a fully pluggable local catalog to store your own data, which includes out of the box catalog implementations for both Solr with Spatial4j extensions and PostgreSQL/PostGIS.
Initially designed to be an integration platform, DDF has transformed into a full-blown complete product with fantastic HTML5 based web user interfaces that allow for data to be displayed on the map tiles of your choice.  Built around the notion of protecting sensitive data, DDF supports simple and complex fine-grained service and data policies that allow for Attribute Based Access Control (ABAC).  The modular framework, which leverages OSGi, allows the user to easily swap out and plug in new components.  
This presentation will provide the information needed to start using DDF in order to simplify your data discovery and analytic needs.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>24-hr Latency End to End Data Processing Using Open Source Technologies for the Airborne Snow Observatory</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=985</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[pramirez]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=985</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[JPL's Airborne Snow Observatory is an integrated imaging spectrometer and scanning LIDAR for measuring mountain snow albedo, snow depth/snow water equivalent, and ice height (once exposed), led by PI Dr. Tom Painter. The team recently wrapped our second "Snow On" campaign where over a course of 3 months, we flew the Tuolumne River Basin, Sierra Nevada, California above the O'Shaughnessy Dam of the Hetch Hetchy reservoir; focusing initial on the Tuolumne, and then moving to weekly flights over the Uncompahgre Basin, Colorado.
To meet the needs of its customers including Water Resource managers who are keenly interested in Snow melt, the ASO team had to develop and end to end 24 hour latency capability for processing spectrometer and LIDAR data from Level 0 to Level 4 products. Fondly referring to these processing campaigns as "rodeos" the team rapidly constructed a Big Data open source data processing system at minimal cost and risk that not only met our processing demands, but taught the entire team many lessons about remote sensing of snow and dust properties, algorithm integration, the relationship between computer scientists, and snow hydrologist; flight and engineering teams, geographers, and most importantly lessons about camaraderie that will engender highly innovative and rapid data systems development, and quality science products for years to come.
Chris Mattmann, Paul Ramirez, and Cameron Goodale for the ASO project will present this talk and will detail the story of the Compute processing capability on behalf of the larger team, highlighting contributions of its key members along the way. We will cover the blending of open source technologies and proprietary software packages that have helped us attain our goals and discuss areas that we are actively investigating to expand our use of open source.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>985</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>Avoiding Burnout, and Other Essentials of Open Source Self-Care</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=986</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kathleen.danielson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=986</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As technical community managers we are faced with a unique set of challenges. Like most FOSS community members, we're often volunteers, but the work we do in moderating mailing lists, planning events, fielding project feedback and contributions, and being the public face of our communities can take an additional emotional toll. We do it because we love our communities, but we also are often guilty of neglecting our own very real needs in order to serve those communities. We end up feeling guilty, run down, inadequate, and ultimately burnt out.

Does this sound like you? Even if you don't do community management work, you might have run into some of the same frustrations. In this talk I'll share with you my own experiences in building and managing different geo communities. Through my own lessons learned, I'll strive to help you think about ways to:

- Ensure you have adequate support in your work
- Build a vocabulary to talk and think about the challenges you face
- Feel empowered to say no and to allow yourself time away from the project
- Recognizing and handling burnout
- Avoiding burnout next time around]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The Mapossum: A System for Creating, Collecting and Displaying Spatially-Referenced Answers to User-Contributed Questions</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=987</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[george.raber]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=987</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This project, originally inspired by the pop vs soda maps (www.popvssoda.com) seeks to create a web application where any question can be asked and answered by anyone with internet access. The Mapossum allows users to visualize spatial patterns in the questions they wish to pose without the need to possess the knowledge necessary to create maps of their own. The application creates a spatial web-survey system that harnesses the visualization power of a web map to explore the spatial components of question. As a tool it has the ability to help users reveal a different dimension of spatial interactions, and provides more insight into cultural and regional interactions.  To accomplish this we have created a framework that abstracts the creation of questions and the logging of spatially referenced responses so that the answers can be mapped as points, or aggregated at various levels of administrative or political units (counties, states, countries). The application utilizes PostGIS/PostgreSQL to store and manipulate the data for the questions, responses, and other spatial data needed to support the application. The information is served as Web Mercator tiles using Python and Mapnik. On the front end these tiles and other data are consumed using the Leaflet JavaScript library. Users have the ability to create questions and the possible responses to these questions, as well as query the responses. The presentation will discuss the framework in detail, and we will demonstrate the use of the application for various types of question – response collection scenarios. The application has potential to be used as a general data collection tool for those collecting data in the field. We are also seeking to include the ability to couple the process of both answering and visualizing responses with social networking sites. The Mapossum couples a web-survey system with the visualization power of a web map to explore questions that have a spatial component to them as so many questions do.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Integrating FOSS4G into an enterprise system for Disaster Management</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=988</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daskov]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=988</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ROGUE (Rapid Open Geospatial User-Driven Enterprise) was a project funded under the Joint Capability Technology Demonstration (JCTD) Program from the U.S.  Department of Defense. Boundless and LMN Solutions, LLC implemented the project, with the Pacific Disaster Center (PDC) serving in the role of project Transition Manager. The project’s goal was to improve the abilities of the OpenGeo Suite to ingest, update, and distribute non-proprietary feature data in a distributed, collaborative, and occasionally disconnected environment. Under this project, PDC integrated the following technologies into its decision support system for emergency managers named DisasterAWARE:
-	GeoGit: Versioned replication of spatial data across multiple sites, supports disconnected editing and conflict resolution. 
-	Arbiter: Android app for field data collection, syncs to GeoNode.
-	MapLoom: GeoNode GUI for spatial data editing and management. 
-	KML Uploader: Functionality to upload KML for storage in PostGIS and served via GeoServer. 
-	GeoServices REST (GSR): Extends GeoServer to publish data using the REST methodology of ArcGIS Server. 

This presentation will cover the integration of these components into DisasterAWARE, along with the security framework implemented for all components.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Repurposing OpenTripPlanner for Ride Sharing</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=989</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[daniel.luxemburg]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=989</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[OpenTripPlanner is an open source application for building multi-modal itineraries using OpenStreetMap data about walking and driving routes and General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS) data for public transit data. With some creative adjustments, OpenTripPlanner can also be used to generate itineraries for ride sharing based on a pool of existing rides. 

This talk will demonstrate taking advantage of OpenTripPlanner's flexibility in this fashion. The example of repurposing OpenTripPlanner will serve as the basis for a more general discussion of ways that functionality relating to geospatial data can be reused in unanticipated ways.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Barriers to FOSS4G Adoption: OSGeo-Live case study</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=990</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tech]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=990</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[OSGeo-Live is a Linux distribution, available in virtual machine, bootable DVD, or bootable USB formats, containing a curated collection of the latest and best Free and Open Source Geospatial (FOSS4G) applications. This talk investigates the correlations between worldwide download distribution, and community participation against indicators of economic, technical knowledge and socio-cultural barriers to geospatial technology and FOSS adoption. Better understanding the barriers of technology transfer are important to the outreach efforts of the FOSS4G community, and understanding the market development potential of FOSS4G around the world.
Results of an analysis of the OSGeo-Live community will be shown but the techniques discussed can be applied to any software project.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>bboxfinder.com - Building the Cascadia Open Source GIS Community one little tool at a time...</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=993</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=993</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Cascadia Users of Geospatial Open Source (CUGOS) is a regional chapter of OSGeo guided by the belief that getting our hands dirty building simple, but useful tools is a great way to learn. First there was projfinder.com, a simple way for people with coordinates in an unknown projection (but with a general idea of where their data is) to find likely projections. Following up on the success of that effort we launched the next in the series of "*finder.com" CUGOS projects, bboxfinder.com.

Built on a simple stack of open source tools, bboxfinder.com aims to be a resource for finding all things related to bounding box coordinates. The website allows users to draw or import shapes from geojson to capture a bounding box for the data. It supports on-the-fly reprojection of coordinates into all EPSG coordinates systems and tile bounds can be visualized as well as identified.

This project, just like projfinder.com before it, has proven to be an valuable teaching and learning tool within CUGOS. Multiple "hack sessions" dedicated to getting active contributors have attracted new developers to participate in the CUGOS community. Finally, this project -- like many things CUGOS does, is hosted on Git Pages making it an accessible and fun project to participate in.

Come learn about the tool, the development process, and how development of these simple tools is building community in Cascadia!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>ERMA - Next generation disaster response from NOAA</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=994</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=994</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ERMA(R) (Environmental Response Management Application) is an online mapping tool that integrates both static and real-time data such as Environmental Sensitivity Index (ESI) maps, ship locations, weather, and ocean currents in a centralized, easy-to-use format for environmental responders and decision makers. Developed by NOAA and the University of New Hampshire with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, U.S. Coast Guard, and the Department of Interior, ERMA provides environmental resource managers with the data necessary to make informed decisions for environmental response.

In 2010, ERMA was chosen as the COP (Common Operational Picture) for all federal, state and local spill responders during the Deepwater Horizon/BP oil spill. Today it remains a critical resource to restoration efforts in the Gulf of Mexico. Leveraging open source technologies, ERMA has been customized with site-specific tools and data for eight different geographic regions and continues to show immense flexibility to adapt and scale to a diverse user base for environmental response.

As we move the ERMA project into the next generation, we are pushing the bounds of how ERMA scales, leverages new technology, and integrates into the government IT ecosystem. This talk will provide an overview of ERMA development and why open source and standards-based approaches were adopted. Learn how ERMA performed during the DWH/BP oil spill response and ongoing restoration efforts. Gain insight on new open-source technologies, tools, collaborative development models and trends that are driving the future of disaster response.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Leaflet.Debug - An unobtrusive debug shim for Leaflet based maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=995</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=995</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Leaflet is the bomb... it is the go-to front-end library for web mapping. Complex at the core for new users and hard to debug, Leaflet is also an elegantly crafted piece of software, employing an inheritance model that creates compact and easily extended code.

Leaflet.Debug has three objectives in supporting the development of web maps based on Leaflet. First, it tries to not get in the way. The core concept of the debug library is to be able to add a one-line JavaScript include in your app for instant benefit. If you remove the one include, the library goes away with minimal impact to the Leaflet name-space and data structures. Second, the debug library dynamically catalogs all classes and instances of Leaflet classes. This dynamic tracking of the inheritance chains and instances of classes makes debugging and tracking down issues in your map easy and fast. Finally, the debug library tries to provide helper functions at multiple complexity levels. In its most basic use scenario, the debug library will warn you if you do not have a simple map object in your map (which is the most common issue for people on #leaflet IRC channel). In more complex scenarios, there are helper functions related to searching for layer instances etc. Using Leaflet.Debug, the hope is that you can stop sprinkling debug code throughout your app and rely on the dynamic capability of a common debug library to help you develop your mapping apps. In the future we are working toward also providing a small pop-up GUI based interface to the debug library to allow even easier exploration of events, objects, and debug capabilities.

In this talk and live demo of Leaflet.Debug we will go over the basics of how the library integrates with the Leaflet architecture, demonstrate the basic capabilities that come standard with the debug library, and demonstrate how to extend the debug library with your application-specific debug needs.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Quadcopter GIS for less than $700 - Hardware and software to map your local community</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=996</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=996</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Quadcopter - Phantom FC40 ($500). Camera - Canon PowerShot ELPH 130 IS 16.0 MP ($110). Opportunity to engage your local community to produce open data - priceless.

Let's get to the point. Let's talk about hardware and software to get out there and actually map some stuff with a quadcopter. This is the story of my adventures hacking with a Phantom quadcopter over the last 10 months to make local maps... and of course have fun. The only rules... it has to be cheap and the software has to be open source.

We will go through the hardware, including purchasing, setting up, and flying the quadcopter. The camera is hacked with CHDK and strapped on the quadcopter with some velcro to a vibration dampener cut up with a dremel tool. The processing software is a pain to install, but we will talk through it including software options, how to get your processing off loaded to your video card GPU, and how we as a community can make all this easier in the future. Finally, we will look at what you can actually make... including mosaics, 3d models, and DEM's of your local community.

Quadcopters are cheap, fun, and amazing for engaging your local community to produce open data. Let's do it!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Small town GIS - Leveraging GitHub, QGIS and community members to manage local data</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=997</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronr]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=997</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Langley is a small rural community on Whidbey Island in Washington State. Like so many other small rural communities, Langley is faced with limited resources but a great need to better understand the geospatial context of the local environment. Through the use of open source tools, including QGIS, GDAL/OGR, PostGIS, GRASS, and others, as well as free open data hosting at GitHub, Langley has started to better leverage existing data and attract community members to participate in gathering new and useful data. Small scale "civic hacking" is alive and well... and provides opportunities and challenges that are both similar and different than that of the larger urban counterparts engaged in large scale civic hacking.

This talk with go over the technical aspects of the workflows that have proven fruitful for engaging local community members of small rural communities in both data creation and curation. We will also look at the social aspects of getting local governments engaged in the process of leveraging community resources for open access to data and tools.

https://github.com/langleywa]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Working with Geonetwork 3.0</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=998</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jesse.eichar]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=998</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the release of Geonetwork 3.0 on the horizon, the first major version change in 10 years, there are many new features and possibilities available for Geonetwork users.

This talk will be an in-depth look at these new features as well as the design of Geonetwork 3.0 focussing on the areas of:

* The new user interface
 * Workflow
 * Customizability
* How to customize Geonetwork 3.0 for your organization.
* The improved modularity of Geonetwork 3.0.
* How to embed the metadata viewer into other non-GeoNetwork web sites and applications.
* Report Generation
* Advanced metadata validation
* And more]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Harmonize, Analyze and Visualize your Data with DDF</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=999</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeff.vettraino]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=999</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This session is targeted toward developers and people who are interested in harmonizing data from various remote data sources.  The Distributed Data Framework (DDF), an open source java project managed by the Codice Foundation, is designed to centralize data for discovery and analysis that might otherwise be distributed across many disparate and remote systems.  The Distributed Data Framework, which was originally developed for use in the US Government and recently open sourced, offers extreme flexibility for securely managing and sharing both local and remote data. 
Users can configure DDF to leverage open source data sources and social media to gather increased intelligence about a particular person or event.  DDF has the ability to crawl and/or submit real time queries against remote data sources.  This session will cover extending DDF to pull data from Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social networking sites in order to discover more information about a place of interest.  This session will also describe how to create additional analytical products derived from the data, and how to expose that information through DDF’s query and notification interfaces.   The modular architecture built on OSGi allows plugins to be added at runtime, which allows new data to be continually exposed and additional analytical algorithms to be included.  Finally, the data will be visualized through a variety of widgets including a 3D globe and heat map.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Hardware Hacking: Make your own GPS/sensor logging devices</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1000</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mikejuvrud]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1000</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[An introductory look at how to build and program your own custom GPS receiver or other field sensor logging devices using open source hardware and software.

As a practical example, we will walk through an Arduino-based, GPS data logger that has been assembled from open hardware components and uses a variety of sensors. In addition to hardware/sensor discussion, the presentation will cover the programming concepts involved in capturing, displaying, and logging data from multiple sensors.

No electronics knowledge is required, as we will focus on Arduino compatible components that most makers with a little programming knowledge can begin hacking together.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>visualizing geospatial datasets using webgl</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1001</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mail]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1001</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Data analysts must navigate increasingly large data sets, sometimes with billions or                                                                  
more records. I present methods for interactive visualization of large data sets, following                                                                  
the idea that perceptual and interactive scalability should be limited by the chosen                                                                  
resolution of the information, not the scale of the data.                                                                                             
I first describe methods for interactive querying using binned plots through a                                                                        
combination of multivariate data tiles and parallel query processing.                                                                                 
I then present a design space of scalable visual summaries that use data reduction                                                                    
methods (such as binned aggregation or sampling) to visualize a variety of data types.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Inception: chaining geospatial analyses through web + desktop feedback loops</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1002</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[swalbridge]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1002</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Geospatial analysis often requires complex software installations, limiting reuse. This talk uses the IPython notebook interactive computing environment, coupled with Geopandas for computation and data manipulation. In addition to the plotting available in existing libraries, this talk also embeds a new library for Leaflet web maps for interactive visualization within the notebook, merging the web and the desktop into a single computing environment.

From this initial analysis, results are stored in Github, and then pushed through the web-based ETL tool koop. Once in koop, we can develop a workflow using web-based routing and watershed analyses, streaming results back into the IPython Leaflet environment. After validation, this workflow can be shared as a chained set of services on a cloud application platform.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Our Cartesian world: does projection still matter?</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1004</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[swalbridge]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1004</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[GIS was born in part by rejecting the strict requirements of surveying, instead blindly digitizing paper maps, which despite their imprecision gave us access to tremendous volumes of digital data. Similarly, great innovation is happening today by discarding precision and standardizing on geographic coordinates to a fixed datum, as commonly done in formats like GeoJSON, and its topological kissing cousin TopoJSON. This talk reviews some of history and trade-offs between these different worldviews, provides a flavor for the geodesic perspective of the world, and finally discusses how I learned to stop worrying and love crappy data.

A quick game of "projection engine telephone" will be played, examining how coordinates with different levels of precision fare after reprojection through projection engines, helping build up an intuition for when we should and shouldn't care about projections. Finally, I'll discuss possible futures of coordinate systems, and what we can do to escape the evil genius running our Cartesian world.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A glimpse of FOSS in the environmental consulting arena</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1005</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jmccrae]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1005</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the highly competitive world of environmental consulting, being able to manage large volumes of data and deliver timely, accurate information based on that data is critical to our ongoing success. As a relatively small company, we recognized that we needed something unique to survive and prosper in an industry dominated by huge corporations. Over the past 7 years we have made a considerable effort to shift over to a FOSS environment with in belief that, not only would this decision enhance what we already do well, but give us the competitive edge we would need to ensure future prosperity.

A brief presentation of a snapshot of our current FOSS status, a workflow tour beginning at the data acquisition stage looking at the feed through our patented EDMS QA/QC system into PostgreSQL followed by a demonstration of a just a few of our many custom web/mobile/desktop applications that rely on the PostgreSQL back end database and how these solutions are able to deliver accurate and timely information to employees and clients alike, and finally, where to next. 

We take advantage of multiple FOSS including the likes of OpenLayers, MapServer, PostgreSQL/PostGIS, PHP, D3 and jQuery.  This combination places us in an ideal position to respond to client needs with the ability to rapidly deliver almost any request.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mining Multi-State Oil Spill Data to Create a Public Map Visualization</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1006</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[josh128]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1006</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Oil spill data is often maintained by state boards of oil and gas. If the data is front-facing and available to the public its often hard to access and limited information about oil spills are shared. 

Using Python and BeautifulSoup, we were able to collect a comprehensive database of oil, brine and other spills in Colorado and New Mexico. Much of the data had no geospatial information and we georeferenced events to the nearest section or quarter section. 

Finally all the data was brought together in a time-filterable, cartodb powered map application.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>EarthExplorer - On-line Search Tool for USGS Remote Sensing Data</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1007</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[sunne]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1007</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The EarthExplorer (EarthExplorer.usgs.gov) system provides on-line search, order, browse and download of Landsat, aerial, LiDAR, and a multitude of other earth science data in support of the United Stated Geological Survey (USGS), Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center.  Last year, the launch of the Landsat 8 satellite has provided over 200,000 additional scenes to the historical Landsat archive.  EarthExplorer was developed to provide a fast, easy to use search engine to allow scientist and general users the ability to search and download data over their area of interest.
  
The EarthExplorer user interface uses open source JavaScript libraries, PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor (PHP), Cascading Style Sheets, and the Google Map API.  

Some of the key features of EarthExplorer include:
•	Fast, geospatial search engine
•	Map viewer for viewing overlay footprints and browse overlays
•	Simple, fast Graphical User Interface (GUI)
•	Data access tool to search and discover data
•	Textual query capability
•	Keyhole Markup Language (KML) export capability to interface with Google Earth
•	Save or export queries, results, and map overlay for reuse
•	Request on-demand products
•	Access to browse images from standard products
•	User authentication service for access to specialized datasets and tools
•	Access to Landsat Data Continuity Mission (LDCM) quality band data
•	Standard product downloads
•	On-Demand Web Mapping Services
•	User notifications of new acquisitions and available products through subscription services

In addition the Bulk Download Application provides a simple tool for users to obtain large quantities of data without user interaction.  Together with the EarthExplroer interface, user are able to obtain large amounts of data from the EROS archives.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MapStory: The next plateau</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1008</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[marino]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1008</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MapStory.org is a community-driven open educational resource that lets people share and peer review observations about how the world evolves over time and space. It’s built on an open source geospatial stack (PostGIS, GeoServer, OpenLayers, GeoNode) and aims to empower both authoritative and public participation in data collection, peer review, and storytelling. We want to use this session to debut a "new plateau" for MapStory that includes an updated user interface with new features, namely integration of GeoGit ‘crowdediting’ of data and XYT frames for MapStories (what we call StoryBoxes).]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Cartography from code...?</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1010</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bjkobben]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1010</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Nowadays we see, specifically on the Web, maps that are interactive, creative, as well as beautiful and effective. And more and more these maps are no longer "drawn", by hand or computer, but "coded". Programmed. 
In this talk we show that with modern programming tools, such as the popular D3 API, the results can be as good or better, even to the most discerning cartographer. And we discuss the question "can programmers be cartographers, or should cartographers become programmers...?"]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Geonode earning its stripes: experiences of deploying and using Geonode in different application domains</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1011</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gmcferren]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1011</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will describe how Geonode is used to provide the spatial data infrastructure (SDI) and content management for oceanographic websites, mine monitoring systems, sensor network systems and environmental hazard systems. The talk will highlight a) different data provisioning approaches for dealing with streaming sensor data, Synthetic Aperture Radar data, b) inclusion of content from less common service interfaces like the OGC SOS, OPeNDAP and c) particular visualization approaches developed for portraying time-series datasets of various kinds. The talk will expand on the experiences of deploying Geonode via Docker.  Finally, a number of interesting ways of extending Geonode to support applications that are monitoring-oriented rather than SDI-oriented are described, such as spatio-temporal data dashboards.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GISCube</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1012</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[boustani]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1012</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As a GIS developer and being part of a compute team at Jet Propulsion Laboratory at NASA and involving in variety of earth science related projects such as RCMES (Regional Climate Model Evaluation), ASO (Airborne Snow Observatory) and Snow Data System, I felt a strong need of GIS and GeoSpatial tools and how these projects are in need of tools, software and codes that can do the GIS processing, data management and visualization.

Based on the strong need for such a tool I decided to develop a GIS application. This application called GISCube and it is an Open Source project. It is a web-based application and acts like a GUI for existing GIS technologies. GISCube is benefiting from variety of Open Source GIS/GeoSpatial libraries and API’s that are active now such as GDAL, OGR, OpenLayers and more.

GISCube has the capability of supporting variety of well know GIS data formats in both vector and raster, and going to support some NASA’s and scientific data formats such as netCDF and HDF files. Visualization section of GISCube can be very useful for scientist, for example, who may not be comfortable with tools that can read data and be able to visualize them easy and fast. The main part of GISCube is Geo-processing tools that are doing processing over data such as data conversion, data management, spatial analysis and more. The benefit of being Open Source project is that the developer society can involve in this project like adding to existing Geo-Processing tools that are available in GISCube and make better.

In FOSS4G 2014 I will give a demo of GISCube and talking about the technologies I have used to develop this application along with some examples of using this project.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Vector Tile Service (VTS): Serving seamless polygons in the browser with TopoJSON and Node.js</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1013</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[luca.morandini]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1013</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This talk will introduce the Vector Tile Service (VTS) which provides a
Node.js-based realisation of a Tile Map Service tiles in both GeoJSON and
TopoJSON. This systems provides a seamless and highly performant user
mapping experience in both OpenLayers and Leaflet.
The key to fast display of vector geometries in VTS lies in the use of
tiles, which 
leverage both local and server-side caching. Whilst linear features lend
themselves easily to tiling through browsers, polygons have traditionally
represented more of a challenge in
reconstructing tiled polygons.
VTS provides further efficiencies by using TopoJSON as a transport format
between 
the server and the client.
VTS implements all these improvements to support web-based vector tiling,
delivering exceptional
performance under heavy load through Node,js and CouchDB-based caching,
and efficient transport through TopoJSON. This talk will cover VTS and
the practical aspects of its implementation together with use cases from
the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN -
www.aurin.org.au).]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1013</wp:post_id>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[13.4.3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

				<title>OpenDroneMap</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1014</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[svm]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1014</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Aimed at developers and end-users, this presentation will cover the current state-of-the-art of OpenDroneMap, toolkit of FOSS computer vision tools aiming to be easy to use for referencing unstructured photos into geography data (colorized point clouds, referenced photos, orthophotos, surface models and more), whether the images be sourced from street level photos, building interiors, or from sUASs (drones).

Currently no such comprehensive FOSS toolkit exists and is easy to use and install. ODM aims to fill this gap.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>ILWIS, the next generation tool framework for GIS and remote sensing</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1016</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[r.l.g.lemmens]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1016</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Integrated Land and Water Information System (ILWIS, http://52north.org/communities/ilwis/) is a GIS and remote sensing software integrating raster, vector and thematic data set processing into a desktop application. ILWIS is hosted under the umbrella of the 52North project and managed and maintained by ITC, University of Twente, The Netherlands. ILWIS is currently subject to a significant refactoring and modularization process referred to as ILWIS Next Generation (ILWIS NG). This will increase attractiveness for developers and lowers their entry requirements. It will provide a sustainable code base for the next decade and allows for integration with other open source software. Beneficiaries are researchers, educators and project executers. It will allow them to use GIS and remote sensing functionality in an easy and interoperable manner on a single desktop and in a web and/or mobile environment in order to integrate their work with others in a standardized way. 
Based on requirements analysis meetings with a small team at ITC, an architecture was created to host the modular components of ILWIS NG. The implementation of this architecture was started in 2013 and comprised the creation of the QT-based core software centered around a plug-in concept which supports connectors. This supports different data formats and interfaces to other software packages. As first extensions, a Python API and WFS have been developed and data connectors to PostgreSQL and OGC’s SWE are underway, as well as a flexible mobile app environment, making it possible to configure lightweight GIS apps within a very short time. 
The presentation will embark upon the justification of starting the software refactoring and will provide an overview of the new modular architecture, giving insight into the design choices which were made. The presentation will also expose the GIS and image processing functionalities within ILWIS and how they are made available in the new interoperable setup indicating the libraries and standards on which they are based. Examples will be given on the many projects in which ITC has used ILWIS already and the potential use of ILWIS Next Generation in combination with OSGEO projects in the future.]]></content:encoded>
