	<item>
				<title>Building Open Source Projects in Government Esri Ecosystems</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1017</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lyzidiamond]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1017</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The challenges that are most commonly discussed by proponents of open source in government technology relate to changing the culture among technical staff and explaining the value of open tools and systems. But beyond the political concerns and misperceptions, there are practical complications in implementing these tools inside proprietary tech ecosystems like Esri. Although it's becoming easier, injecting open source into the Esri stack can be convoluted, to say the least.

For all of its challenges, however, there have been many successful open source implementations in all levels of government, from open data portals to full-scale applications. Using case studies from recent Code for America projects, this talk will identify some of the more difficult challenges and highlight a few techniques for integrating open source geo tools into the Esri stack with a focus on minimizing difficulty for the developer and maximizing benefit for the end user. The talk will focus on web applications and tools while touching on data interoperability, spatial analysis, and trainings/documentation.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Esri-Leaflet: Super-charge your mapping apps with GIS Services</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1018</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1018</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Leaflet is an awesome light-weight, pure JavaScript mapping API.  Leaflet also has a powerful plug-in model that the community can use to extend and enhance the basic mapping functionality.  This session illustrates how JavaScript developers can leverage the Esri-Leaflet extension to enhance their mapping apps with ArcGIS basemaps, demographic maps and feature services.  We’ll also show you how to quickly build in other functionality such as geocoding and finding directions, and also how to perform OAuth against the advanced authenticated services.  So if you need to power your apps with GIS services, stop by to learn how to make the most of this plug-in.]]></content:encoded>

Bootstrap-map-js is an open source project that illustrates how to leverage the new Bootstrap 3 framework to build responsive mapping applications.  This session will cover the key concepts required to build mapping apps that work well on web, tablet and mobile devices using Bootstrap-map-js.  This include topics such as how to avoid css clashes, effectively using the grid system, and how to make your maps auto-resize and re-center on all devices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Automated Vehicle Location (AVL)</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=991</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 31 May 2014 16:04:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bbasques]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=991</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Using OpenLayers and GeoMoose web clients, MapServer and the PostgreSQL/PostGIS database packages, we’ve built a live view for our Automated Vehicle Locating (AVL) system, as well as custom geographic reporting tools. This talk will cover why we chose to build our own web viewer instead of using a commercial package, and reasons to use the existing Open Source web viewers. We’ll also show how the feed from the commercial AVL vendor was translated into the Postgres database in order to build out a smooth end user experience. There will also be discussion on standards for the database tables and records in order to make the system plug and play for others interested in customizing a live AVL web viewer on their own. Some production services will be demonstrated in a live view mode.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>991</wp:post_id>

	<item>
				<title>Broad Street Maps</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1020</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anna]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1020</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We design and implement mapping projects for global health organizations. Our clients ask themselves: why are certain people or places disproportionately affected by health problems? Many organizations collect data in an effort to answer this question, but this data typically exists as a spreadsheet. Broad Street Maps believes in the power of visual data to inform decisions and communicate impact. Using open-source technology, we turn static spreadsheets into dynamic maps in order to better understand the social and geographic determinants of health and to ultimately improve the delivery of care.

We are operating under the assumption that our maps can improve the delivery of healthcare to people in need. We believe that strengthening an organization's operations and systems results in greater local impact in the community. We believe that maps specifically help organizations build capacity by informing decision-making, demonstrating impact and attracting donors, revealing patterns and identifying vulnerable populations.

We are focused on partnering with organizations that work in “last mile” communities. Oftentimes, these organizations don’t have access to critical geographic information as basic as roads, administrative boundaries, or locations of neighboring clinics. With the development of tools such as OSM, geographic information is increasingly being incorporated into the work of global health organizations. Unfortunately, many of the small-scale organizations that we partner with don’t know where to start looking for this geographic information or how to make it useful for their work. Our services help our partners create a more comprehensive picture of the complicated ecosystem in which they work, helping them to plan more targeted intervention strategies. 

We use a variety of open source tools to produce the final deliverables for our partner organizations. Some of these tools include QGIS, the INSTEDD products, and MapBox tools. We are interested in exploring new tools, and want to focus on those that are most appropriate for our partners and the resource-limited settings in which they work. To that end, we have thought about designing a new platform that would combine the most useful features from all of these toolsets and would also be customized to the global health context.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>State of the (Geo) Gem</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1021</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[scooterwadsworth]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1021</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[According to its creator, Yukihiro "Matz" Matsumoto, "Ruby is designed to make programmers happy." While it may not achieve this goal for everyone, it works for at least one programmer (me). When developing spatial applications however, the seeming lack of support for Ruby can serve to diminish programmer happiness. The aim of this presentation is to show that Ruby, with the right gems, and an occasional bit of JRuby sprinkled on top, can make spatial programmers truly happy.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Building a (Digital) National Park Service Map</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1022</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nate_irwin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1022</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The NPMap team has an ambitious goal: Creating an accessible, custom, and dynamic (“real-time”) map for each of the 400+ National Park Service sites. Each of these maps is handcrafted to match the National Park Service’s rich graphic tradition, and can be used in both web maps and mobile applications.

To support this goal, the team has built a flexible geospatial platform on top of a number of open source software projects, including PostgreSQL/PostGIS, Node.js, MapBox, CartoDB, OpenStreetMap, Leaflet, Twitter Bootstrap, and Maki. This platform eliminates the technical hurdles that have traditionally been associated with building digital maps, making it possible for Parks to build and maintain their own map(s).

This talk will dive into what exactly a National Park Service map is, and will also go into detail about the NPMap team’s geospatial platform.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>GeoMesa: Distributed Spatiotemporal Analytics</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1023</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonyfox]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1023</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The rapid growth of traditional and social media, sensors, and other key web technologies has led to an equally rapid increase in the collection of spatio-temporal data.  Horizontally scalable solutions provide a technically feasible and affordable solution to this problem, allowing organizations to incrementally scale their hardware in tandem with data increases.

GeoMesa is an open-source distributed, spatio-temporal database built on the Accumulo column-family store.  Leveraging a novel spatio-temporal indexing scheme, GeoMesa enables efficient (E)CQL queries by parallelizing execution across a distributed cloud of compute and storage resources, while adhering to Accumulo's fine-grained security policies.  GeoMesa integrates with Geotools to expose the distributed capabilities in a familiar API.  Geoserver plugins also enable integration via OGC standard services to a much wider range of technologies and languages, such as Leaflet, Python, UDig, and QuantumGIS.  

In this presentation, Anthony Fox will discuss the design of spatio-temporal indexes in distributed “NoSQL” databases, the performance characteristics and tradeoffs of the GeoMesa index, and how it can be leveraged to scale compute-intensive spatial operations across very large data sources.  This discussion will detail how GeoMesa distributes data uniformly across the cloud nodes to ensure maximum parallelization of queries, and other computations.  Specific computationally intensive analytics include distributed heat map generation over time, nearest neighbor queries, and spatio-temporal event prediction.  He will present common analytic workflows against spatial data expressed as batch map-reduce jobs, dynamic ECQL queries, and real-time Storm topologies.  Using the Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone (GDELT) dataset as a working example source, Mr. Fox will demonstrate how a completely open-source architecture stack, including GeoMesa, enables ad-hoc and real-time analytics.

This presentation will be of interest to data scientists, geospatial systems developers, DevOps engineers, and users of massive Spatio-Temporal datasets.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Web and mobile enterprise applications</title>
		<link>https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1024</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[peter.batty]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://2014.foss4g.org/?post_type=session&#038;p=1024</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This presentation will discuss enterprise web mapping and mobile applications that we've been developing for large utilities and communications companies, based on a number of open source geospatial components, including PostGIS, MapFish, GeoServer and Leaflet. It will discuss development of offline mobile applications using both PhoneGap to compile to native applications on Android, iOS and Windows, using a SpatiaLite database, and also use of HTML5 offline storage. We will discuss ideas on how to create extremely easy to use but still powerful applications, using approaches inspired by consumer web mapping sites rather than traditional GIS. The presentation will not be deeply technical but will include material of interest to developers as well as end users and managers.]]></content:encoded>
